result.title: Objective
result.description: Development Objective: To reduce GHG emissions via the introduction of a new energy source and propulsion technology for urban buses. Immediate Objective: To demonstrate the operational viability of FC drives in urban bus and their refueling infrasctructures under Brazilian conditions.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. CO2 emissions from SÃ£o Paulo buses decreased by 1,560 tones

baseline.comment: 0 tones

target.comment: 1,560 tones

actual.comment: 13 Comments: The overall goal of reduction of CO2 emissions will not be achieved in this Project due to the reduction of the number of vehicles initially expected and delays in the construction of the buses which did not allow a longer operation period. Considering the extension of the Project until December 2015, 47 tons of CO2 avoided emissions are expected to be achieved given that the 03 new buses were launched in June 2015 and tests will be run until the end of the year.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Buses are operated for 1,000,000 vehicle-km, that operational statistic can be gathered.

baseline.comment: 0 vehicle-km

target.comment: 1,000,000 vehicle-km

actual.comment: 8,274 Comments: As explained in the MTE, the mileage goal will not be achieved in this Project given the reduction of the number of vehicles initially expected and the delays in the construction of the buses, which did not allow a longer operation period. Considering the extension of the Project until December 2015, only 30,000 vehicle-km are expected to be achieved. However, during the final evaluation, the calculation of estimated mileage from other experiences of FCB will be agregated to this indicator. By MTE, the mileage for Ballard Fuel Cell engines amounted to 3,971,608 bus-km worldwide.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. The amount of vehicle-km obtained in the prototype operation

baseline.comment: 0 vehicle-km

target.comment: 256,000 vehicle-km

actual.comment: 8,274 Comments: The prototype ran 8,274 km up to date. During the last years, it faced several technical issues related to traction system and eletric components. After those were solved, the fuel cell presented problems caused by the non-use of the vehicle. The project has spare parts to change it, however, the technical teams from Bus integrator were concentrated on building the 03 new buses and could not allocate technical teams for this first task. We expect that this issue is resolved after the beginning of the tests of the 3 buses of Phase II.3 of the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. The amount of vehicle-km obtained in up to 4 buses operation

baseline.comment: 0 vehicle-km

target.comment: 744.000 vehicle-km

actual.comment: 0 Comments: - As analysed during MTE, the mileage of 03 new additional buses will not be fully achieved. The buses of the Phase II.3 were tested in the first half of 2015 (functional tests). The normal operation is expected to begin in the second half of 2015, with expected mileage of 21,600 km until December 2015.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Significant demonstration of the operational viability of fuel cell drives in urban buses and their refueling infrastructure under Brazilian conditions.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 5. Prototype operation level in km per year

target.comment: 30,000 km per year

actual.comment: 8,274 (accumulated) Comments: As previously mentioned, the prototype is not working at this point time since all Consortium efforts have been allocated to operation of the 03 new FCBs. The technical reports of the prototype demonstrate the reasons for non-functioning over the last years.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 6. Up to 4 buses operation level in km per year

baseline.comment: 0 km

target.comment: 40,000 km per year

actual.comment:
0
Comments: It is expected that each bus runs around 7,200 kilometers (in average) until the end of the Project, considering the extension of the Project until December 2015. Unfortunately, given delays in building the buses, the time for testing and operations has reduced considerably. The FTE will present an analysis of delays, failures and their respective impact on timing for the buses and project as a whole. Overall, the construction of the new buses was impacted both bureaucratic issues related to importing of foreign equipment and parts, and unfavorable market conditions for the national partners of the automotive sector which affected production and resources within the industry itself.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 7. Refueling station operated satisfactorily to supply sufficient H2 at reasonable cost. Indicator: system availability percentage

actual.comment:
1
Comments: - The hydrogen production station was inaugurated in June 2015. The functional tests of the buses of Phase II.3 were made with hydrogen already produced in the station. The Petrobras operation staff was trained by Hydrogenics and is able to operate the station. However, some adjustments are necessary in order the station is fully operational and the final milestone is reached. The required visa for technicians is being requested by the company.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 8. Prototype breakdown level under 20,000 km

baseline.comment: 0 km

actual.comment:
8,274 km
Comments: The prototype ran 8,274 km and it is not operational in this PIR period because of some traction system problems, that we expect may be resolved after the beginning of the tests of the buses of Phase II.3, when the breakdown level will be evaluated. Because it is a prototype, it is expected to experience some technical problems at the operation. That being said, the breakdown level reached is not superior to the target. It should be mentioned that originally this was not caused by the fuel cell technolgy itself, but rather by auxiliary systems. The lessons learned with the prototype were incorporated into the design of the 03 new FCBs and foreign equipment was replaced by national parts to 60% of the total buses.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 9. Up to 4 buses breakdown level under 50,000 km

baseline.comment: 0 km

actual.comment: 0 - to be tested. Comments: - When the buses are ready for operation, expected in the second half of 2015, the availability data will be collected. However, the testing with the prototype made available technical information that feed the design of the 03 new buses. As assessed in the MTE, the 03 new FCB have robust technological design and it is expected that the target is achieved after the duration of this specific project.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Cadre of bus operators and staff trained in operation, maintenance and management of fuel cell buses.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 10. Number of operators / maintenance staff trained for the prototype

baseline.comment: 0 employees trained

target.comment: 4 employees trained

actual.comment:
22
Comments: - the number of drivers and maintenance staff needed for the operation of the prototype was achieved. Another group of drivers and maintenance staff wil be trained for the operation of the Phase II.3 buses during the second semester of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 11. Number of operators / maintenance staff trained for the up to 4 buses

baseline.comment: 0 employees trained

target.comment: 10 employees trained

actual.comment:
0 - to be undertaken in second half of 2015.
Comments: The next training, for an expected number of 22 drivers and maintenance staff, will take place in the second half of 2015, when the buses of Phase II.3 will start normal operation.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 12. Enrollment in training seminars

baseline.comment: 0 training seminars

target.comment: 15 training seminars

actual.comment:
2
Comments: - Another Fuel Cell Bus workshop will be given by the Consortium in the second half of 2015, when the buses of Phase II.3 are expected to be in operation. It should noted that this component would be financed with counterpart resources which did not totally materialize and, therefore, the targets could not be achieved.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Accumulation of a substantial body of knowledge about reliability, failure modes and opportunities for improving the design of fuel cell buses for Brazil

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 13. Development of quarterly reporting forms Evaluation: development completed = 100%

actual.comment: 40% Comments: - With the regular operation of the buses in the second half of 2015, there will be enough data to develop quarterly reports. Thus, we expect the achievement of the target after buses operation. However, daily reports on buses performance are being undertaken and will be consolidated quarterly.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 14. Persons consulted in formulating reporting guidelines; quarterly reports collection. Evaluation: task done = 100%

actual.comment: 100% Comments: The main variables to be collected and analyses to be done are already known, so there is no need to consult other persons to develop the reports. With the regular operation of the buses in the second half of 2015, there will be enough data to develop quarterly reports.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 15. Publication of documents demonstrating accumulated experience and knowledge. Evaluation: task done = 100%

actual.comment: 50% Comments: - The three buses of Phase II.3 are expected to be in operation in the second half of 2015, when technical documents are expect to be published, reporting the operation in the end of the Project. However, it should be noted that most of financial resources for this outcome were from co-financing which was cancelled by FINEP.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Assessment of performance of electrolysis unit.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 16. Development of quarterly reporting forms Evaluation: development completed = 100%

actual.comment: 50% Comments: - The hydrogen production equipment is expected to be in normal operation in September 2015. The Petrobras technicians are working with Hydrogenics to develop the reports with all the data needed to the assessment of the operation of the station. With the regular operation of the station, the goal is expected to be achieved until December, 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 17. Persons consulted in formulating reporting guidelines; quarterly reports collection Evaluation: task done = 100%

actual.comment:
100%
Comments: - The reporting guidelines are being prepared by Hydrogenics and Petrobras, not being necessary to consult persons from other companies to achieve the goal.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 18. Publication of documents demonstrating accumulated experience and knowledge. Evaluation: task done = 100%

actual.comment:
0%
Comments: - With the regular operation of the station, a final report of the operation of the station will be published until the end of the Project, achieving the goal. However, it should be noted that most of financial resources for this outcome were from co-financing which was cancelled by FINEP.

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: Proposal for Phase III of the Brazilian Fuel Cell Bus Program

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 19. Satisfactory preparation of the Phase III proposal based upon Phase II experience, reconfigured bus design, Brazilian standards and continued dialogue with vendors. Evaluation: task done = 100%

actual.comment: 0% Comments: - Phase III is not applicable at this project stage given that cofinancing resources for this purpose were cancelled. A strategy for continuation of Fuel Cell technology development in Brazil is being constructed with interested partners.

result.title: Outcome 6
result.description: Increased awareness and support of the public for an increased role for fuel cell buses in Brazilâ€™s urban transport system

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 20. Number of local, national and international workshops/seminars held and attended

target.comment: At least 80

actual.comment: 80 Comments: - Presentations of the Project are being held. In this PIR period, the project was presented at: i. UITP - International Association of Public Transport - Conference held in Rio da Janeiro - Brazil - November 5-7, 2014; ii. UFABC - Universidade Federal do ABC - Seminary held in São Bernardo do Campo - Brazil - March 2, 2015; iii. AEA - Associação Brasileira de Engenharia Automotiva - Seminary held in São Paulo - Brazil - April 25, 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 21. Number of professional publications produced

target.comment: At least 40

actual.comment: 70 Comments: - Technical papers were produced for presentations in conferences and universities.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 22. Number of reports in media

target.comment: At least 300

actual.comment: 320 approx. Comments: - The Project has been disseminated in the media through radio, interviews, TV program, specialized papers and magazines. Due to the launching event in June, 2015, there was a big number of reports in the media.

result.title: Objective
result.description: A field tested protected area management strategy is adopted for the effective conservation of a representative sample of mangrove ecosystems in Brazil

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1.Populations of threatened and overexploited species, selected as indicators of improved protection from threats in pilot UC
Eudocimus ruber
Ucides cordatus

baseline.comment:
tbd
tbd
(Final selection of species and monitoring methods and frequencies will be determined by end of inception phase).
# threatened species per pilot areas:
Par: 1
Cear/Piau­/Maranho: 5
Maranho: 1
Para­ba: 1
SoPaulo/Paran: 23
Remain the same as at

target.comment: Remain the same as at project outset

actual.comment:
The project elaborated the Programme for Monitoring of Biodiversity in Federal UCs with Mangroves; it takes into consideration exploited and non-exploited species of fauna and flora in mangroves areas, and presents a cluster of Rapid Assessment Protocols (RAPs) for prioritized species (according to Secretariat of the Convention of Biological Diversity 2006, and Secretariat of Ramsar Convention, 2005, 2010). The selected species include the Eudocimus ruber (commonly denominated Guará: non-exploited) and the Ucides cordatus (commonly denominated Uçá Crab: exploited), that are mentioned in the project as indicators for conservation of biodiversity of mangroves areas.
The project elaborated ToRs and started actions for data gathering and meta-analysis: findings will be available by the end of 2015 (two specialized services have been purchased).
U. cordatus is one of the most investigated species in Conservation Units of Brazil (CUs): preliminary indicative data on stock estimation can be obtained in applied researches in the Cassurubá CU (Schmidt 2008, 2010 and 2012), and in APA CIP (Pinheiro 2013). U. Cordatus also allows to make substantial and scientific-based inferences on climate change, as it it sensitive to environmental alterations (e.g. rains, temperatures).
E. ruber is relevant as nests are only in mangrove woods, hence the nest monitoring allows to indicate effects on environmental alterations (e.g. mangrove health, pollution). Some data are available in CEMAVE/ICMBio (National Center for Research and Conservation of Wild Birds), specifically for Cururupú CU (Resex in Maranhão state), Mamanguape River CUs (APA and ARIE in Paraiba State), and in Cananeia-Iguape-Peruibe CU (APA in Sao Paulo).
Furthermore, the project started several activities in order to develop and fully implement the participatory monitoring of biodiversity (e.g. SocMon methodology, focused on social-environmental indicators), and to harmonize those tools and protocols through an appropriation process within the ICMBio (i.e. ongoing consultancy, leaded by the competent department COMOB/DIBIO/ICMBio), in order to guarantee sustainability and ownership of outputs (see outcome # 4).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Vegetation cover of mangroves in project intervention UCs

baseline.comment: 568,000 hectares

target.comment: At least the same as at project start

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
3. % of mangrove ecosystems in mangrove UCs under management categories or other legal instruments that allow sustainable use (SU) and or limit any use and targets strict conservation (SC)
Eudocimus ruber
Ucides cordatus

baseline.comment:
tbd
(Final selection of species and monitoring methods and frequencies will be determined by end of inception phase).
# threatened species per pilot areas:
Par: 1
Cear/Piau­/Maranho: 5
Maranho: 1
Para­ba: 1
SAO Paulo/Paran: 23

target.comment:
Network Targets (Indicative)
Unit, #UCs % SU %SC
I (tbd) 25% 75%
II (tbd) <70% tbd
<!--70-->
<!--70-->
<!--70-->III (tbd) 50% 50%
IV (tbd) 45% 55%
V (tbd) 55% 45%
VI (tbd) 50% 50%
VII (tbd) 30% 70%
The Project will design a network of areas with a good balance of SU and SC instruments in key locations. The targets above are indicative and will be determined as part of project.

actual.comment:
There is an error in the text of the indicator. The PRI format reports the text of the indicator #1. The right text is: % of mangrove ecosystems in mangrove UCs under management categories or other legal instruments that allow sustainable use (SU) and/or limit any use and targets strict conservation (SC) Examples of legal instruments for SU other than management categories is in the take zones.
The project adopted in its elaboration the physical-environmental criteria discussed by the World Bank and the WWF, in order to identify eco-regions with mangroves. Seven eco-regions were identified in Brazil:
UNIT I: from Mouth of Rio Oiapoque to Mouth of Rio Araguari (AP)
UNIT II: from Mouth of Rio Araguari (AP) to Colares (PA)
UNIT III: from Colares (PA) to Parnaíba Delta (MA/PI)
UNIT IV: From Parnaíba Delta (MA/PI) to Rio Guajú (RN/PB)
UNIT V: Form Rio Guajú (RN/PB) to BA/ES boundary
UNIT VI: from BA/ES boundary to Cabo Frio (RJ)
UNIT VII: from Cabo Frio (RJ) to Barra do Sul (SC)
When the project was elaborated (2004/2005), there where 132 CUs: 89 CUs belonged to the Sustainable Use categories and 43 to the strict conservation ones. Nowadays, there are 162 CUs: 94 in SU category (58%), and 68 in SC category (42%).
Unit (# CUs) % SU %SC
I (3) 0% 100%
II (7) 72% 28%
III (21) 86% 14%
IV (16) 75% 25%
V (55) 62% 38%
VI (14) 57% 42%
VII (46) 37% 63%
It should be noticed that the project prompts and supports the creation and enlargement of several CUs of the SU category (i.e. RESEX - extractive reserves, in Amazon coastal area of Pará en Maranhão states). During the reporting period, the project supported the creation if three RESEX and the enlargement of one in Pará (October 2014), and is involved in the creation of other five RESEX and the enlargement of one in Pará and Maranhão. More details in indicator # 1 of the outcome # 2.
Finally, we mention that the present indicator takes into consideration the categories of the CUs as a whole. However, within each SU conservation unit, the project supports the elaboration of official management tools (such as the Management Agreements in Salgado Paraense, and te Management Plans in APA CIP and Mamanguape). Those tools establish the zoning of the CUs and the allowed use of each zone, thus SC percentage is higher than reported, due to the fact that parts of SU units are no-take zones (logically assimilated to strict conservation areas).

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. % Management effectiveness (METT) of pilot mangrove PAs

baseline.comment:
METT applied during PDF B on a sample of pilot UCs:
Poor: 1%
Fair: 61%
Good: 27%
Excellent: 1%

target.comment: 70% Pilot UCs with a METT score of Good/Excellent

actual.comment:
As mentioned in PIR 2014, there is an ongoing debate within the ICMBio on most adequate tools and processes for monitoring and evaluation of effectiveness of CUs and their performance in conserving biodiversity. In-progress processes are:
- Harmonization between METT and RAPPAM (the official tool of the Ministry of Environment). The purpose of the project is to use a tool whose values/results can be monitored in the future and compared.
- Development of an ICMBio system for M&E of effectiveness of CUs and management support to CUs managers in planning and decision making, leaded by the Directorate for Creation and Management of CUs – DIMAN/CGCAP.
In any case, the METT will be applied as planned, and it will be completed with inputs form other sources (e.g. RAPPAM; ongoing study on financial sustainability of CUs with mangroves, in the frame of output # 1.3, outcome # 1). So far, according to 2012 METT (applied in the frame of the MTR): poor 8%; fair 58%; good 38%; excellent 0%. However, it must be mentioned that some criteria of the METT format applied in in 2012 are different from those used in 2007, finalscore changed, thus the comparison with baseline METT is not linear.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 5. % of other pilot PAs testing 1 or more of financing strategies developed in the project

actual.comment:
The study on financial sustainability of CUs with mangroves is under elaboration. The Brazilian Fund for Biodiversity (FUNBIO) is the partner for the elaboration of the study, in alliance with sector-specialized NGOs. Study includes training for CUs managers and civil servants and recommendations of specific financial tools in specific areas. It must be mentioned that FUNBIO is an implementing partner of the GEF MAR project, also executed by the ICMBio: a similar activity is expected in GEF MAR on financial sustainability of marine and coastal CUs. The project stimulated the dialogue and articulated with GEF MAR staff: the ongoing study represent phase # 1 (elaboration of strategy, definition of good practices, recommendations, training; advocacy at federal level) and it will be continued within the GEF MAR (implementation; advocacy and incidence; institutionalization).
On the other hand, during the reporting period, the project supports the Mosaic Lagamar in the negotiation of financial support though parliamentary amendments at state and municipal level, in order to capture a percentage of environmental compensations generated by the CUs that are part of the mosaic (the payment of environmental services and ICMS-E, among others). It is a recommendation of the Diagnostic on Normative Framework in Mangroves Areas, elaborated by the project in 2012: The project staff considers it as a concrete initiative on financial sustainability, and the evaluation of the experience will feed the ongoing study.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: 6. % of Environmental agencies that have agreed to and signed to the Mangrove Plan

baseline.comment:
State IBAMA =0%
OEMAs=0%
Coastal municipalities
in clusters = 0%
out of cluster =0%

target.comment:
State IBAMA =100%
OEMAs=100%
Municipalities
in clusters = 80%
out of cluster =60%

actual.comment: No data to be informed yet. As mentioned in PIR 2014, the Plan is the collection of good practices and learned lessons of the whole project, and it is expected in second semester of 2015. According to monitoring plan, this indicator will be reported at the end of the project. Nonetheless, we mention that the PAN (National Action Plan for Mangroves) was finalized and promulgated by the ICMBio: it gives substantial inputs to the Plan. Participants to the PAN are IBAMA, states (OEMAs) and municipalities, along with academic communities and civil society organizations. The mentioned actors and stakeholders validated the PAN (Normative Instrument N° 1 published on January 29th 2015).

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: 3. % of mangrove ecosystems in mangrove UCs under management categories or other legal instruments that allow sustainable use (SU) and or limit any use and targets strict conservation (SC)

baseline.comment:
Baseline information is still incomplete to measure accurately the exact % of mangroves under SU and SC in UC or if it is representative sample of different mangrove types
(see data below for: #UCs, %SU, %SC)

target.comment:
The Project will design a network of areas with a good balance of SU and SC instruments in key locations. The targets above are indicative and will be determined as part of project.
(see data below for: #UCs, %SU, %SC)

actual.comment: Error in PIR format. There is no indicator #7 in the Logical Framework of the project.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: The enabling environment for a sub-system of mangrove ecosystem protected areas is in place, including policy, regulatory, and financial mechanisms

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. % of â€œMangroveâ€? States with a set of norms and guidelines agreed with and coordinated between federal, state and municipal agencies on the management of mangroves.

baseline.comment: 0 % of the States

target.comment: At least 80% of the States

actual.comment: More than 50% of states where the project intervenes adopted the Normative Instruction 09072013 dealing with the crab transportation (4 states over 7; Piaui, Ceara, Maranhão and Pará). Furthermore, several initiatives are under implementation: a) the project works for the elaboration of guidelines on qualified management agreements for the mangroves areas (until September 2015, based on the ongoing experience in “Salgado Paraense” Pilot Area); b) the PAN-mangrove was published in January 2015; c) regulations for mangroves in the framework of the Management Plan of the APA CIP (under elaboration), as benchmark for future management plans in CUs with mangroves; d) constitution and functioning of the Technical Chamber for Water Resources within the council of the APA Barra do Rio Mamanguape (activation in May 2014; results expected in October 2015). Finally, several activities of the project contribute to the advocacy strategy for the discussion and modification of parts of the New Forest Code (Law nº 12.651, May 2012). As mentioned, the Law allows the increase of shrimp and salt production in mangrove areas.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Existence of a core group of trained staff members (of IBAMA/ICMBIO, OEMAs and/or municipal agencies) capable of implementing and using those norms and regulations

baseline.comment: < 30% of States have core group of trained staff in key aspects of mangrove management By end of year one full staff competency skills specific for mangrove UC manager will have been defined and baseline and end targets determined

target.comment: All OEMAs (BA, CE, MA, PA, PB, PI, PR, SP) involved, have a core group of staff-members trained in procedures of licensing & enforcement for mangrove conservation At least 1 more specialized staff in agency for mangrove management in each case

actual.comment:
- Training on IN09072013 and the use of baskets for crabs transportation, implemented by the SEPAq (Secretary for the Development of Agriculture and Fishery of the state of Pará), which is a relevant partner of the project in “Salgado Paraense” pilot area. So far, 1.700 fishermen were trained (approx. 35% women) in 11 CUs, of whom approximately 100 are communitarian leaders and civil servants.
- Implementation and expansion of the “Protagonist Youth” training action; in 2015, the project elaborated and started modules for CUs managers, in order to train them and turn them into replication agents, and to expand the training activities with communitarian leaders at local level.
- Training activities on SocMon for CUs managers and technicians (an internationally applied methodology for social-environmental monitoring). In 2015, one training workshop was realized; 32 civil servants participated. In the second semester of 2015, more training activities will be realized.
- Training activities in Pará state are under implementation, in the frame of the elaboration of Management Agreement of nine RESEX. Activities involve and train civil servants at local level, especially those from municipalities and Pará public institutions. Number of trained people will be reported in next report.
- Training activities in “Delta do Parnaiba” pilot area started in June 2015, in order to elaborate the Crab Management Plan. In the frame of the Plan, 40 meetings (workshops and training activities) are designed for public sector personnel.
- In APA CIP and Lagamar Mosaic pilot area, more than 400 people participated to training activities and workshops in the frame of: a) elaboration of the APA CIP Management Plan (approximately 30% of participants are civil servants, mostly at municipal level); b) cartographic and thematic database management (more than 80% of participants are civil servants, especially CUs managers and personnel of environmental agencies at state level).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. # regulations tailored to mangroves in at least: UC management categories management plans guidelines financing mechanisms integrating water planning to mangroves fisheries management plans for mangrove UC

baseline.comment: 0 0 0 0 Measures for fisheries management are insufficient to provide sustainability

target.comment: 2 1 for each management category 4 1 resolution presented to CNRH linking classification of water bodies upstream from mangroves to needs of these ecosystems 1 resolution outlining rules and procedures for ecosystem-based, integrated fisheries resources management

actual.comment:
UC management categories:
The project supports the development of the management agreements for 9 RESEX in Pará state. The outcomes of this process will support the elaboration of guidelines for management agreements at national level, specifically for CUs of sustainable use.
Management plans guidelines:
Considering that CUs with mangroves are mostly in a category for sustainable use, the project prioritizes guidelines for RESEX (Extractive Reserve) and APA (Environmental Protection Area).
- Management Plan of the APA CIP; the zoning considers the several existing instruments (such as Municipal Plans for Environments, Directors Plan, Management Plans of other Conservation Units inside the APA, Ecological Economic Zoning of the States for São Paulo and Paraná, among others).
- Participation to the deliberative / consultative councils and to the Technical Committees of the Conservation Units in pilot areas. Thematic calendars have been defined for each council (e.g. urban expansion, climatic change, zoning, traditional communities) as well as working groups, in order to better perform the duties of the councils.
- Elaboration and diffusion of the Guidelines for Managers and Counselors of the Councils of Federal Conservation Unites, elaborated by the CGSAM/DISAT.
Financing mechanisms:
- Study on financial mechanism in CUs with mangroves, in order to elaborate a national strategy. The execution of the diagnostic and strategy is responsibility of FUNBIO. The project already linked this action to the GEF MAR project: implementation/test, training activities, and a continuum strategy on financial sustainability in coastal and marine CUs will be maintained in the GEF MAR.
- Mosaic Lagamar (APA CIP Pilot Area) in the negotiation of the financial support though parliamentary amendments at state and municipal level, in order to capture a percentage of environmental compensations generated by the CUs that are part of the mosaic.
Integrating water planning to mangroves:
- Specific actions and programmes for the management of water resources have been designed and officially approved within the PAN Mangrove.
- A Technical Chamber for Water Resources has been activated within the Management Council of the Mamanguape APA and AIRE. The project is developing the diagnosis of water resources and a monitoring protocol on water quality. The Chamber will develop and promote research, data sharing mechanisms and mitigation actions through competent bodies.
- The management plan for the APA CIP pilot area is proposing programmes and regulations on water resources quality, with emphasis on the mangroves conservation.
Fisheries management plans for mangrove UC:
- Crab Management Plan for the Delta do Parnaiba Pilot Area (APA and RESEX), with FADESP and Goeldi Museum is. The participatory process will finish in December..
- Management agreements for 9 RESEX in Pará state: fishery activities are the main issue of the management agreements.
- Management of a critical situation in October/December 2014 in APA CIP, and participated to the modification of an excessively restrictive measure of the State of São Paulo on fishery activities of some species. The project staff collected data and elaborated a technical report that led to the modification of the Decree at state level, the re-allowance of supervised fishery activities, and the designation of APA CIP as responsible for census and authorization of fishermen for those species (linked to stock monitoring activities).

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. Composition/source of financing in the project intervention areas that will develop new financing strategies

baseline.comment: UC funding comes from Federal and State budgets with an average funding gap of 50% in mangrove UCs

target.comment: Tested mechanisms increase PA funding 30% in the two pilot intervention areas (Bahia and SP)

actual.comment: The action is under implementation with FUNBIO, as mentioned in other sections. According to monitoring plan, this indicator will be reported at the end of the project, as part of the outcome of the METT.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 5. Existence of a national mangroves plan in Brazilâ€™s Wetland Plan

baseline.comment: No plan . Activities for conserving mangroves are ad hoc and un-coordinated with on-going plans and programmes

target.comment: Mangrove Plan agreed and legally formalized as part of Wetlands and contributes to target of national PA Plan

actual.comment: As mentioned, the National Plan will be developed by the end of the project. Eventually, the project staff participates to the meetings of the National Commission for Humid Zones, where advocacy activities already started in order to gain incidence in the wetland plan (e.g. the application of the APA CIP to Ramsar site has been accepted and it is now supported by the Commission and the Ministry of Environment).

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Replicable models are in place for the management of mangrove resources in SNUC sustainable-use protected areas.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Degree of ecosystem management of fisheries resources in Para
# hectares under integrated fisheries resource plan
# no-take areas in the 3 pilot UCs

baseline.comment:
0 ha under fisheries resource plan that limit practices and catches.
0 no-take areas agreed

target.comment:
70,000 ha under ecosystem-based, integrated fisheries resource plan.
3 no-take zones agreed

actual.comment: # hectares under integrated fisheries resource plan: Approximately 300.000 ha. As mentioned in PIR 2014, the following CUs participates to the development of the Management Agreements: Soure (27.464 ha); São João da Ponta (3.203 ha); Mãe Grande de Curuça (37.062 ha); Maracanã (30.019 ha); Chocoaré- Mato Grosso (2.785 ha); Tracuateua (27.153ha); Caeté-Taperaçu (42.068 ha); Araí-Peroba: (50.555 ha); Gurupi- Piriá (74.081 ha).Furthermore, three new CUs (RESEX category) were created in October 2014 in Pará state, with the support of the project: Cuinarana (11.037ha); Mocapajuba (26.465ha); Mestre Lucindo (21.029ha). The project already realized actions with the aim to include those new CUs in ARPA (Programme for Protected Areas in Amazon), in order to guarantee the consolidation of those CUs beyond project lifespan. The project is also supporting the creation and enlargement of CUs in Pará, and Maranhão. It must be mentioned that this action created the most large continuous protected area of mangroves in the world (a non-interrupted coastal area from Pará to Maranhão), as reported in several media (See articles and releases in Communicating Impact section). # no-take areas in the 3 pilot UCs: The projects projection is to define and approve no-take zones in at least 7 CUs in Pará state. No-take areas have been identified in the management agreements of the RESEXs. Communities are elaborating rules about the exploitation of natural resources. By now, the project is supporting the development of qualified management agreements for the RESEXs in the Salgado Paraense. Although Management Agreements are tools for each CU, it must be noticed that those are the firsts that embrace an ecosystem-based approach and that define the management of the whole area (nine RESEX), including common zoning and regulations.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
2. Degree of exploitation of the uÃ§a crab resources PiauÃ­/MaranhÃ£o/CearÃ¡
% mortality rates
decrease in capture rates and maintenance of income
Up-take of model

baseline.comment:
60% mortality in uÃ§a crab
21 tons uÃ§a crab and income of 40-60US/month
No resource management plans exist for Uca crabs in sustainable use UC

target.comment:
25% decrease in mortality and harvesting at levels established in resource plan
20% decrease in capture of uÃ§Ã¡ crab and income remains same or higher
Model is incorporated in official practices and policies and replicated in 1 UC cluster

actual.comment: In the areas where the baskets have been tested according to the IN 09072013, the mortality rate is lower than 25%, actually achieving less than 5%, according to collected data in RESEX Sao Joao da Ponta. The IN is already adopted in four states (North / North-East); the project started an action to evaluate the IN effectiveness, in order to adapt the regulation to local contexts, along with the ICMBio/DISAT, the UNESCO and the NGO Conservation International.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Development and marketing of new Mangrove products

baseline.comment:
At present, most local communities and populations lack the capacity to produce and market potential new products from mangrove areas
18 families involved in sustainable economic alternatives to uÃ§Ã¡ capture

target.comment:
100 potential local small entrepreneurs trained in the preparation of a business plan
100 families in the pilot UCs involved in sustainable alternatives including women and youth

actual.comment: According to Substantial Revision (January 2014), the focus of the project moved from market access of mangroves products to market promotion and income generation through land planning and management tools. Management agreements in Salgado Paraense pilot area, and the Crab Management Plan in Delta do Parnaiba pilot area are the most relevant actions of the project in order to achieve the outcome. Several data show that developed technologies and tolls (e.g. the normative on crab transportation, zoning and stock monitoring) had relevant impact on income of vulnerable and poor coastal communities: e.g. average weekly revenues for fishery activities at household level for families that adopted the crab transportation technology rise from R$ 130,4 to R$ 198,2, representing 24% increment.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. Number of UC and cluster management councils reaching agreement on harvesting levels and enforcement in Pilot areas

actual.comment: At least 20 CUs applied and/or are elaborating regulations and rules: Management agreements in Salgado Paraense pilot area, and the Crab Management Plan in Delta do Parnaiba pilot area are under elaboration; the Working Group on Fishery of the APA CIP council reached agreements that led to the stock monitoring and fishermen census, and norms are under elaboration within the Management Plan.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description:
Conservation of mangroves is improved by piloting the alignment of UC management with
sectors and spatial planning

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. # of water management instruments agreed upon by the Mamanguape waterbasin committee that take into
account the water quantity and quality for mangroves

baseline.comment: 0 of 6

actual.comment:
So far, two management instruments were defined: a) the activation of the Technical Chamber for Water Resources within the Management Council of the “Barra do Rio Mamanguape” APA and AIRE; b) a monitoring protocol on water quality.
The two management tools have been defined and approved by the APA and ARIE councils. Eventually, a diagnostic of water resources is under implementation through an external consultancy, it is: a) a baseline for the monitoring protocol; b) a database and diagnostic for the elaboration of proposals and programmes by the Chamber. The Chamber will develop and promote research, data sharing mechanisms and mitigation actions.
It must be noticed that:
1) There is not a unique water-basin committee; the two water basin committees (Upper and Lower) participate of the Chamber;
2) SUDEMA (authority for environment in the state of Parnaiba) already monitors some parameters. The defined protocol complements those parameters and communicate with SUDEMA database. The Aquatic Mammals Foundation (FMA) also shared relevant data on flora and fauna. The two stakeholders participate to the councils and to the Chamber.
3) The monitoring protocol will be applied by students of the Federal University of Parnaiba. The university participates to the council and to the chamber; the in-the-field work of the students is in the frame of the Inter-institutional Collaboration Agreement between the APA and the university: it is costless for the ICMBio and it will be applied during next years (continuity; technical and financial sustainability).
4) Private sector representatives participate to the councils and to the chamber. Most relevant are the association of shrimp producers and the union of sugar cane and alcohol producers. Indigenous communities are also represented (communitarian leaders), along with FUNAI (National Fund for Indigenous People).
The project expect the approval of at least one more management tolls. The Chamber is discussing the elaboration of technical proposals, with the aim to turn them into management instruments for water resources: a) Action Plan with contingency measures based on agreed alarm-level monitored indicators; Terms for Conduct Adjustments (TCA); new inter-institutional collaboration agreements.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
2. Degree that mangrove conservation is incorporated in Zoning of the ReentrÃ¢ncias Maranhenses APA
Zoning restriction on main sectors reflected in UC plan
# municipalities agreed on APA zoning
% of the key actors in APA have signed a formal document of adherence to zoning regulations

baseline.comment:
Initial zoning for agro-ecological activities, shrimp farming, and indicators starting for deforestation but reflected in PA-planning and management.
1 municipality in the APA has a development plan that considers mangrove needs zoning.
0% of the key actors in APA have signed a formal document of adherence to zoning regulations

target.comment:
UC management plan reflects zoning and limits of all main economic activities
16 municipalities (200,000 ha.) in the APA have agreed on the zoning.
50% of the key actors in the APA sign formal document of adherence to zoning regulations.

actual.comment:
Two main outputs contribute to the outcome and this specific indicator:
1. The APA CIP management Plan. So far, 42 meetings/workshops have been done, involving almost 700 people. Six municipalities have part of their territories inside the APA CIP limits, representatives participate to workshops and to the elaboration process.
Mangrove conservation has been included in Management Plan as a cross-cutting issue in all thematic and geographic components of the Plan, and a specific zone has been created (Mangrove Conservation Zone). Three geographic sectors have been identified. Thematic clusters have been defined: traditional communities; water resources; urban expansion; climate changes; fishery and aquaculture; agriculture and farming; tourism; non-fishery natural resources.
Zoning was concluded and it will be presented between the 25 of June and the 15 of July, along with specific regulations and restrictions for each sector. Specific mangrove protection area have been mapped and included in the Plan. The Plan is elaborated with a broad participation of social stakeholders, indigenous and traditional communities, organized civil society (e.g. universities; NGOs and foundations), public authorities at municipal, state and federal level. So far, municipalities participates to the process.
2. The Action Plan of the Lagamar Mosaic was elaborated and it is now under revision and validation. The project promoted and supported the creation of the management mechanism in the Mosaic. The Mosaic is composed by 54 CUs with different jurisdictions. The project supported the Mosaic in the elaboration of a single cartographic and bibliographic database, along with the “Atlantic Forest and Climate Changes” Project of the Ministry of Environment, supported by the German Cooperation (GIZ and KfW), with which the project maintains synergies.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Mangrove-related outreach, dissemination and adaptive management is increased.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Awareness among private and public stakeholders on the management of mangrove UCs and the ecosystem services they provide.

baseline.comment: TBD by survey in first six months.

target.comment: Increased by at least 30% compared to baseline survey

actual.comment:
The indicator will be reported by the end of the project, after the application of a random-sample survey about people perception on mangroves.
1. Awareness and dissemination campaigns have been organized and executed, especially in the frame of the “Protagonist Youth” initiative, that already mobilized more than 500 people at community level in Pará state, 30% of which are women.
2. Communication over ecosystem services will be realized as part of the dissemination and knowledge sharing of the outcomes of the FUNBIO ongoing study on financial sustainability of CUs with mangroves.
3. The international seminar for the participatory monitoring of biodiversity was a relevant forum where the project participated and communicated mangrove status and project outputs and outcomes. It was realized in September 2014 in Manaus, with the participation of more than 250 people.
4. The project along with the Coordination for Production (ICMBio/DISAT/COPROD) is executing the last phase of a systematization process (started in 2014), focused on successful experiences of economic, social and cultural inclusion in Sustainable Use marine and coastal CUs. Nine experiences were systematized; the project is now finalizing las in-the-field missions, validating the information, editing the texts.
5. A video was realized by the Coordination for Environmental Education (ICMBio/DISAT/COEDU), with the participation of the project: “Extrativist Citizens” (which means people of the RESEXs).
6. Massive communication campaign was realized during last months of 2014 (articles on blogs, national and stat newspapers and magazines, interviews in national and local televisions). We enjoyed a positive visibility conjuncture, thanks to the creation of three new RESEX with mangroves in the Para State, that constitute the largest continuous protected mangrove area in the world. The issue was also published in the official blog of the President Dilma Roussef (more data in Communication section).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Frequency and quality of monitoring of mangrove land cover

baseline.comment: Uncoordinated individual state M&E programs

target.comment: M&E programs coordinated and linked to national system

actual.comment:
1. Data on extension of cover vegetation of mangroves in Brazil and in Pilot Areas are under elaboration with CSR-IBAMA (see information reported for indicator # 2 of the Objective). CSR monitors the mangrove coverage every year.
2. The Programme for Monitoring of Biodiversity is under development, with the intent of harmonizing all monitoring tools and protocols on mangroves (e.g. fishery resources stock monitoring; threatened species; PAN Mangrove; participatory monitoring). The process is executed through external consultancy and leaded by the Coordination for Monitoring for Biodiversity (ICMBio/DIBIO/COMOB).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Number of instances in which adaptive management takes place taking into account M&E results

actual.comment: As mentioned in PIR 2014, internal M&E task has been enhanced since 2013: data on efficiency, financial and technical resources, processes and effectiveness over indicators achievements are monthly elaborated and reported to project coordination, and supports strategy reviews, implementation of activities, and decision making. The M&E functions, along with the adoption of operative tools, allowed the optimization of resources and a more result-oriented approach (i.e. the SIMA – System for Information Management, Monitoring and Evaluation, which will be used in other ICMBio projects).

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. Number of replications of the Project pilots Brazilâ€™s in other mangrove PA

actual.comment: The indicator will be reported at the end of the project, as part of the replication strategy. So far, it shall be mentioned that: a) management agreement will be replicated by the ICMBIo in at least the three new CUs in the state of Pará; they share the Pará mangrove-amazonian coast and the natural resources of the nine RESEX already involved in the elaboration process; b) the “Protagonist Youth” initiative is adopted by the ICMBio and training modules for CUs managers are under execution in order to turn managers into replication agents; c) the technology for crab transportation has been adopted in four states and its evaluation and replication is supported by the ICMBio.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. EE offer fully functional in private and public building sector. 2. EE Product and Service providers trained. 3. Number of public projects under the Public Buildings Initiative (PBI) approach.

baseline.comment: 1. Limited capacity in term of EE offer from local market players. 2. Limited capacity of EE product and service providers. 3. No tender process for public buildings.

target.comment: 1. EE market capacity building strategy in place. 2. Up to 1,400 EE product/service providers trained (ESCOs, equipment providers, building owners/ managers/associations, engineering associaciations, education institutions, universities, etc) by the end of the project. 3. Initiatives on Public Buildings undertaken.

actual.comment: 1. Capacity Development Plan Revised and two new Technical Cooperation Agreements stablished in the private sector with Green Building Council and ABESCO (National ESCO Association) to help implement capacity development activities and disseminate EE business model. A company was hired to elaborate 2 practical guides (Building Certification/Labelling and Energy audits) and 8 videos on PBE Edifica (National Building Labelling Program) that will be used in trainings and dissemination activities in the public and private sectors. Total of 400 people trained on EE financing and PBE Edifica. 2. 1 x 8hs training (50 participants) for banks and ESCOs on evaluation of EE projects; 11 x 4hs workshop ( 209 participants) on PBE/Edifica - Brazilian Building Labelling Program- for private (3 workshops) and public (8 workshops) sectors . 5 x 20 hs training (16 hs presential + 4hs distance learning) on PBE Edifica (146 participants). 3. The PBI approach should be considered more as a partnership with public agents working on energy efficiency than an independent initiative within the project. In order to achieve a higher number of procurement process of EE projects in the public sector and indicate best ways to implement EE projects, a public call was launched to gather energy consumption data from public office buildings. 320 buildings data were gathered and this information is being analyzed and structured in a benchmarking of energy consumption, which will define a consumption indicators for public buildings (KWh/m2). 20 buildings will be selected for energy audits and at least five buildings will be assisted (juridically and technically) to procure and implement energy efficiency projects.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To foster EE investments in private and public buildings in Brazil.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Increase in the number and in annual revenues of EE project developers

baseline.comment: Very few buildings owners/operators have incorporated EE measures

target.comment: Increase in investment in EE for building public and private sectors by USD93 million

actual.comment: The Project is intensively informing and training service providers and project developers about the normative instruction (IN 02) and PBE Edifica. The Planning Ministry (MPOG) has launched an ordinance in Feb 2015 that stablishes best practices and monitoring indicators for energy use in public buildings. MPOG is being technically assisted by the Project. In 2015 Brazil was considered to enter recession, the prices of energy rose 60% and energy efficiency came back to the deabte, however, the interest rates and the availability of financial resources decreased, there is a potential for speeding and enhancing the number of EE projects, but it unclear if EE investments will peak.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Rate of public and private building owners/operators reported to use ESCOs services to improve their energy consumption (at least 80%)

baseline.comment: Govt. buildings operation do not specify minimum EE performance values

target.comment: Local banking system provide financing in 70% of EE projects

actual.comment: There is a huge complexity to measure the utilization of EE services for the total building stock, once only in the federal sphere there are 28.000 buildings. However, through a 5 month public call, the Project has managed to identify energy consumption detailed data from 320 public buildings office to define the baseline of consumption and specify performance values.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Number of FI offering energy savings guarantee services to other sources

baseline.comment: Professionals and developers do not understand basic EE principles

target.comment: At least 10 FIs and value (at least $ 123M in total) of financed EE investment enabled by the Project, including by local FIs

actual.comment: Two regional Banks (Desenvolve São Paulo and AgeRio - Estate Foment Agency of Rio de Janeiro) have been assessed and aproved by IDB to use the EEGM. BNDES is part of the Consultive Committee and has been very active. The Project is trying to enhance cooperation with National Bank Associations and Federations (ABBC and FEBRABAN) and the reestructuring of PROESCO might increase the number and amount of financed projects.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. Number of new EE implemented projects using the EEGM or other similar mechanism due to the Project

baseline.comment: Financing institutions are not aware on how they can support the development of EE market

target.comment: At least 250 projects implemented, resulting in direct CO2 emission reduction of 2 MT CO2 and post-project and indirect 16 MT CO2.

actual.comment: Since last PIR 1 more letter was issued by EEGM to APS Engenharia (total of 4 letters). EEGM has the total of 4 closed projects and there is a current pipeline of 7 more, 2 of which are in final negotiations. The four closed totaled US$1.6M, leveraging US$ 10 million. It is important to note that the goal of 250 projects considered some assumptions that did not occur (total revolving of resources in year 3 and small ize of projects), therefore the resources available in EEGM and the demonstrative projects implemented by component 2 shall achieve 35 to 40 projetcs nationally in the best scenario.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enhanced EE investments through CB in EE in private & public buildings

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 5. EE offer fully functional in private and public building sector

baseline.comment: Limited capacity in term of EE offer from local market players

target.comment: EE building market capacity building in progress by Yr 1; · Efficiency Improvement in Brazil reinforced by Yr 5

actual.comment: Capacity Development Plan Revised and two new Technical Cooperation Agreements stablished in the private sector with Green Building Council and ABESCO (National ESCO Association) to help implement capacity development activities and disseminate EE business model. A company was hired to elaborate 2 practical guides (Building Certification/Labelling and Energy audits) and 8 videos on PBE Edifica (National Building Labelling Program) that will be used in trainings and dissemination activities in the public and private sectors. Total of 400 people trained on EE financing and PBE Edifica.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 6. EE Product and Service providers trained

baseline.comment: Limited capacity of EE product and service providers

target.comment: Up to 1,400 EE product/service providers trained (ESCOs, equipment providers, building owners/ managers/associations, engineering associaciations, education institutions, universities, etc).

actual.comment: 1 x 8hs training (50 participants) for banks and ESCOs on evaluation of EE projects; 11 x 4hs workshop ( 209 participants) on PBE/Edifica - Brazilian Building Labelling Program- for private (3 workshops) and public (8 workshops) sectors . 5 x 20 hs training (16 hs presential + 4hs distance learning) on PBE Edifica (146 participants).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 7. Increased awareness and interest by market players in implementing EE measures

baseline.comment: Limited awareness activities conducted by the Authorities on the benefits of EE

target.comment: Up to 5,000 people from public and private building sector trained; . 2,000 stakeholders reached with project publications and; . 1,000 unique visitors to project website six months after site is launched.

actual.comment: Average of 12.000 accesses monthly in Projeteee (http://projeteee.ufsc.br) a reference online plataform developed to support the design of new efficient buildings. Dissemination of lessons learnt in the labelling of MMA buliding by distribution of 3.000 copies of the publication "Practical Guide for energy efficiency - the experience of project labelling from MMA( Ministry of Environment)". The Project created a visual identity and developed a series of dissemination materials ( folders, banners, logo, ecobags, pencards). The Project's website is active and hosted in MMA's webpage under Climate/Energy: http://mma.gov.br/clima/energia/edif%C3%ADcios

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Access to EE services and commercial financing for public sector buildings enhanced with a PBI

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 8. PBI Program for Public Buildings operational by end of project, including EE tender processes alternatives

baseline.comment: The current purchasing mechanism for public sector is lowest cost only

target.comment: Model for PBI designed by end of first year; · Public sector EE Promotion plan drafted and submitted to the Gov. for adoption by the end of Yr 2.

actual.comment: Despite of PBI not being structured as described in PRODOC, the Project is partnering with the most important initiatives in the public sector to promote energy efficiency such as: Programa Esplanada Sustentável (PES), Programa A3P (Environmental Agenda in the Public Administration) with the Secretariats of Information Technology and Logistics (SLTI) and Federal Budget (SOF), both from the Planning Ministry and PROCEL (Brazilian Energy Conservation Program) to improve and enhance the results and impacts of existing initiatives to promote energy efficiency. Conclusion of the direct contract of CBCS (Brazilian Council for Sustainable Construction) to implement a benchmarking of energy consumption in public buildings (offices) aiming to define indicators and implement 20 energy audits in public buildings in order to identify best cases to demonstrate procedures for procurement of EE projets. The project is providing technical assistance for the consolidation of the Normative Instruction IN02 SLTI and the Ordinance 23 (both elaborated by the Planning ministry) and aimed at defining energy efficiency standards and monitoring procedures for public buildings.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 9. Number of public projects undertaken by ESCOS under the PBI approach.

baseline.comment: No tender process for public buildings under performance contract

target.comment: Average of 15 RFPs/year based on PBI approach.

actual.comment: The PBI aproach should be considered more as a partnership with public agents working on energy effficency than an independent initiative within the project and the number of 15 RFPs anually based on PBI might be infeasible to accomplish. In order to achieve a higher number of procurement proccess of EE projetcs in the public sector and indicate best ways to implement EE projects, a public call was launched to gather energy consumption data from public office buildings. Given the difficulty to recieve data it was extended to 5 months 320 buildings data were gathered. This information will be analysed and structured in a benchmarking of energy consumption, which will define a consumption indicators for public buildings (KWh/m2). 20 buildings will be selected for energy audits and at least five buildings will be assisted (juridically and technically) to procure and implement energy effciency projetcs.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 10. ESCOs develop and implement pilot projects on public sector buildings

baseline.comment: Limited experience in ESCO projects in public buildings

target.comment: Five pilot projects for public building sector by the end of Yr 3.

actual.comment: Executive projects for the retrofit of MMA ready. The Retrofit project has recieved Procel Label, which is issued to most efficient projects (triple A - lighting, envelope, air conditioning). This was the first federal building in Brasilia to have PROCEL label and it broke the paradigm that the building envelope could not be A at the Esplanada. In order to implement the EE measures the eletric project and digital network projects are being procured. Given the budget restrictions in the whole public sector in 2015, MMA will have to search for alternative sources to implement measures and is partnering with ANEEL (National Electric Energy Agency) and local utilities to identify resources available for implementation.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Interest enhanced in the replacement of energy-inefficient CFC-using chillers

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 11. Number of professionals trained on replacement of energy inefficient chillers (CFC and non-CFC)

baseline.comment: No professionals trained

target.comment: 120 professionals (ESCOs and entrepreneurs) trained.

actual.comment: The indicators of component 3 have chaged substantially once this outcome was turned into a new Project BRA12/G77. The chillers inventory showed that there are very few chillers operating with CFC in Brazil and that there are aprox. 130.000 equipments in operation with HCFC-22. Therefore, HCFC was included in the spectrum of chillers approached by this outcome. Outcome1 (BRA12/G77): National Inventory of CFC and HCFC developed. Indicator: Number of CFC chillers in Brazil assessed.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 12. Technical guidelines for CFC chiller replacement prepared and used

baseline.comment: No technical guidelines in place.

target.comment: 02 practical guidelines published and at least 60 professionals using them.

actual.comment:
The company SOMAR was hired to implement the capacity development activities and and to develop the technical guidelines. Technical articles and content of capacity development activities and guidelines under development.
BRA12/G77 - Outcome 2: Technical and information materials to promote and disseminate results achieved with CFC and HCFS chillers developed and distributed.
Outcome 3 - Workshops and trainings to specialized professionals and building owners interested in the replacement CFC and HCFC chillers implemented.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 13. Chiller replacement programme in place.

baseline.comment: The inventory of CFC-based chillers is accepted as 1,000 centrifugal chillers

target.comment: Up to 40 CFC-based chillers replacement demonstration projects using MLF co-financing implemented by the end of Yr 2.

actual.comment:
A public call to select 2 buildings in the private sector in São Paulo to implement retrocomissining in cold water conditioning systems opened. The retrocomissioning will be developed and reported as best practices in publications and trainings.
BRA/12/G77 - Outcome: Retrocomissioning Processes in chillers with CFC e HCFC developed.
Indicator: 04 retrocomissioning (2 in the privat sector and 2 in the public sector).

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: EEGM made available to stimulate EE investment through ESCOs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 14. The EEGM is operational

baseline.comment: No EEGM in place

target.comment: EEGM procedures and rules in place by end of Yr 1; EEGM fully operational and placing guarantees by the end of Yr 2.

actual.comment: EEGm is operational ans local administrator has made 503 visits or/and contacts with clients or partners for possible future EEGM deals. One more letter issued to APS Engenharia in the amount of US$ 735.530,00 leveraging around US$ 1.600,000 in investments in retrofits of more than 50 units on retailer chain Renner. Dissemination of EEGM and EE financing models in 4 events to more than 220 paticipants (SE4All - Chile, SECOVI - SP, 2 at ABESC) - SP);

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 15. Number of ESCOs and/or financial institutions using portfolio guarantees such as the EEGM

baseline.comment: Few ESCOs can borrow from commercial Banks; they use ANEEL fund and own money or partly client money

target.comment: At least 250 projects approved under the EEGM and provided with guarantees

actual.comment: One more letter issued to APS Engenharia in the amount of US$ 735.530,00 leveraging around US$ 1.600,000 in investments in retrofits of more than 50 units on retailer chain Renner. EEGM has the total of 4 closed projects and there is a current pipeline of 7 more, 2 of which are in final negotiations.

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: Project monitoring and evaluation support

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 16.  Monitoring plan fully executed as per PRODOC

baseline.comment: None

target.comment: 100% of planned Project monitoring and evaluation activities completed

actual.comment: Elaboration of Progress Report to ABC (Brazilian Cooperation Agency). Elaboration of Substantive Review (final corrections under development to be submitted to the UNDP/GEF). Strategic Planning of activities of the second half of the Project. Realization of 3 Technical Committee meetings. Revision and upgrading of Capacity Development Plan
