result.title: Objective
result.description: The main development objective of the project is to enhance the capacity to manage and dispose of PCB waste in a sustainable manner and by extension to minimize risk of PCB exposure to the population and the environment.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Number of reviewed and approved standards and rules for PCB management

baseline.comment: 1. Incomplete and fractured legislation, guidance and PCB programs

target.comment: 1.1 Complete, actualized and eficient standards, guidelines and rules for PCB management.

actual.comment: Project Coordination is following up the process of CONAMA Council. According its procedures, the draft text of the Resolution was amended and approved by the Technical Board. The draft Resolution was then submitted to the Legal Board and is now being evaluated/reviewed in order to be submitted to the Plenary voting during its 120th Ordinary Meeting (expected to take place in November 2015).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2.Number of adequate registered and capacitated facilities for PCB decontamination and destruction

baseline.comment: 2. PCB management infrastructure not meeting international standards and without adequate training mechanisms

target.comment: 2.1. Sustainable infrastructure for PCB management, including decontamination and safety disposal in a timely fashion.

actual.comment: Inventory Guidelines for PCB Management" and "Guidelines for PCB Management and Phase-Out" were revised and are now available at the Ministry of the Environment website (at Chemicals Safety Division link).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
3.1.Number of PCBs management regulations developed and approaches tested.
3.2. Number of demonstration projects completed.
3.3. Number of inventoried PCB equipments

baseline.comment: No PCB management demonstration projects complying with international standards completed

target.comment:
3.1. Guidelines and rules for PCB management tested at the demonstration projects
3.2. Four demonstration projects executed at Energy Utilities and PCB contaminated sites
3.3. At least three demonstration projects for inventoring PCB equipments concluded

actual.comment:
For the first demonstration Project, a consultancy was contracted to hiring implementing evaluation of a potential contaminated site in Curitiba, Parana, in South Region of Brazil.
Procurement to hire a company to carry undertake the 3 demonstration projects (on inventories, destruction of PCBs finalized based in Manaus, Amazonas and Recife, Pernambuco and Curitiba, Parana).
Activities should be developed from August, 2015 to April, 2016.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Strengthening of legal, administrative and standardized procedures framework for the PCB management and disposal

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. 1. Number of legislative/regulatory amendments to respond to legislative gap developed

baseline.comment: Brazil has a regulation banning the use of new PCBs. However, there are major gaps in legislation framework and enforcement policies related to the management and environmentally safe disposal of PCBs

target.comment: 1.1. A Comprehensive and complete PCB legislation developed and established to ensure PCB management.

actual.comment: Draft resolution proposed aiming to establish 3 years deadline for the complete inventory and a gradual elimination schedule on the energy sector and industry holding PCB. Beside the regulatory approach, demonstration projects will be carried out, beyond training and communication activities as well, in order to stimulate them to full fill their obligations under Stockholm Convention.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 1. 2. Number of stakeholders and representatives from interested sectors (governamental and private) involved on public policies aiming environmentaly safe PCB management

baseline.comment: Consultations have started with two workshops in 2008.

target.comment: 1.2 All stakeholders, from interested sectors, fully engaged in supporting PCB management plan

actual.comment:
NGOs actively engaged in national debate on treatment options towards the environmentally sound management of PCB.
Energy sector, analytical labs and industry, as well as NGOs and federal government representatives actively engaged in the negotiations under CONAMA on the national regulations on PCB management.
Energy companies willingness and engaged in the demonstration projects planning and preparations.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
1. 3.1. National standards for equipment labeling developed
1.3.2. National PCB Inventory

baseline.comment: No government complete inventory and no labeling standards for PCB equipments.

target.comment:
1.3.1. Labeling of equipment established
1.3.2. Inventory software developed and inventory data entry smoothly continuing

actual.comment:
Labeling of PCB equipment established.
On going consultations among Ministry of the Environment, RCSCLAC in São Paulo, Brazil/Environmental Agency of São Paulo State (CETESB) and Federal Agency for the Environmental Protection and Natural Resources (IBAMA) on a PCB inventory data basis and knowledge system.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 1. 4. Number of Guidance and standards for PCB management

baseline.comment: Outdated and incomplete guidance material and standards

target.comment: 1.4. Full set of guidelines and standards developed for PCB management

actual.comment: Guidance and standards on management of PCB were prepared and made available to enable sound management and elimination, including equipments and oils.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Outcome 2: Management of identified PCB oils and PCB contaminated waste and equipment in partnership with the private sector in a manner that minimizes human and environmental exposure

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 2.1. Number of laboratories certified to standards to complete PCB management and enforcement efforts

baseline.comment: Uncertainties on PCB analytical techniques and laboratory certification system (not meeting international standards)

target.comment: 2.1. A nationwide qualification system for analysis laboratories and PCB treatment facilities developed

actual.comment: Laboratories supported to be able to be due certified for PCB analysis through a training program about Quality Management Systems for quantitative analysis of PCB applying Brazilian Normatives (ABNT NBR 17025:2005 and ABNT NBR ISO 13886:2005).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2.2. Number of quality standards and certification systems for PCB quantitative analysis

baseline.comment: Uncertainties on results from PCB analytical techniques and laboratory certification system

target.comment: 2.2. Development of quality standards and certification system for analytical laboratories

actual.comment: Existing standards and certification systems for analytical laboratories evaluated and considered sufficient to meet the national demand on PCB management.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 2.3. Number of facilities acording to the best available technologies and standards for PCB waste treatment in Brazil

baseline.comment: PCB treatment and destruction facilities not meeting international standards

target.comment: 2.3. PCB treatment and destruction facilities, acording to the best available technologies, with capacity to meet demand while adhering to national standards

actual.comment:
4 plants for decontamination of PCB equipments located at Sao Paulo, Paraná and Minas Gerais identified.
3 incinerators licensed for processing PCB wastes, located at southeast and northeast regions identified.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 2. 4. Number of stakeholders contacted and in agreement with national PCB management plan

baseline.comment: List of stakeholders preliminary and incomplete

target.comment: 2.4. Development of a comprehensive list of technical stakeholders and their roles in the PWMDS

actual.comment:
Adequate list of stakeholders and sufficient information from PCB treatment facilities.
Stakeholders engaged on Project activities.
Lists of services for PCB management regularly updated.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 2.5. Number of technicians from Government staff (environmental agencies) and from Energy Utilities trained in PCB management

baseline.comment: No coordinated PCB training programs

target.comment: 2.5. Development of a national PCB management training program and transfer to the stakeholders from governamental and private sectors

actual.comment: The four (4) demonstration projects mentioned above include training activities for, at least, 120 technicians from environmental government agencies and Utilities. Farther, capacitation in Quality Management Systems for Laboratories must include about 60 beneficiaries from PCB analysis sectors and a Course EAD in PCB Management also is been planning for include almost all of PCB donors technicians.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description:
2.6.1. Management plan published
2.6.2. Number of guidance documents published

baseline.comment: No targets for phase-out set yet and guideline documents outdated

target.comment:
2.6.1 Development of a PCB management and phase-out plan
2.6.2. Development of accompanying guidance documents;

actual.comment: Basis set for the revision of the "The Guide for PCB Inventory " and also the "National PCB Management and phase-out Plan" delivered in 2011, based on the summary of the information and discussions carried on under the seminar on treatment of PCB held in 21st to 22nd, July 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: 2.7. Number of PCB owners aware of Brazils PCB phase-out plan and legislation

baseline.comment: Awareness of PCB management issues almost non-existent among general population and majority of PCB owners

target.comment: 2.7.1 Development of awareness raising program to ensure country-wide knowledge of standards, regulations and practices, for the mainly PCB donors.

actual.comment: "Communication Plan" prepared, including specific strategies to the targeted audience as PCB holders, NGOs and federal and state governments.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Outcome 3: Environmentally sound storage and disposal of identified PCB waste by demonstration projects

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 3.1. Number of demonstration projects of PCB equipment decommissioning and treatment/destruction

baseline.comment: No projects meeting international standards have been completed

target.comment:
3.1. Successfully testing the revised standards and regulations according to international practices.
At least three demonstration projects of PCB equipment decommissioning and treatment/destruction

actual.comment: Demonstration projects are considered of great importance to validate, in practice, the Guidelines developed by this project and proposed Regulations for the development of the National PCB inventory and the implementation of the PCB Management Plan, as well for the remediation of contaminated sites and adequate disposal of PCB wastes.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 3.2. One fully compliant PCB storage site established by PCB owners for viewing, training and verification of standards

baseline.comment: No formal storage sites have been established

target.comment: 3.2. Testing PCB disposal options environmental suitability and economic viability for both pure and low-contaminated PCB waste (disposal of approx 1000 tonnes of PCB).

actual.comment:
Implementation of the three (3) demonstrative projects in Power Companies includes preparation of an action plan for deactivation of PCB equipments and subsequent PCB destruction, always concerning about environmental and safety standards.
Besides, The National Coordination is planning to extend the Project deadline for more 2 (two) years, in order to execute specific demonstrative projectc aiming PCB destruction at storage sites.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3.3 Number of certified temporary storehouses as demonstrations and training venues

baseline.comment: No demonstration sites.

target.comment: 3.3. To have all three demonstrated sites accomplished according with PRODOC guidelines.

actual.comment: As mentioned above, if the Project could be extended for, at least, 2 years, in a cooperation with the Power Sector, the National Coordination aims to execute specific demonstrative project for testing PCB destruction from storage sites.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 3.4. Four (4) demonstration sites executed and technicians from the environmental agencies and PCB owners trained

baseline.comment: Consultations have started with two workshops in 2008.

target.comment: 3.4. Use of several PCB treatment demonstration projects to validate guidelines and standards, use for training purposes and for viewing by stakeholders

actual.comment: As mentioned above, each one of the four (4) demonstration projects include training programs for the stakeholders and also include closure workshop for discussing the results for the demonstration activities. The workshop will also look to the next steps for implementing recommendations for PCB Management and Action Plan, aiming compliance of Stockholm Convention deadlines.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To create the conditions for sugar mills to increase the export of electricity generated by sugar cane trash and bagasse to the grid.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Trash system implemented and operating

baseline.comment: No mills or distilleries are using the trash produced by the green harvesting

target.comment:
Trash system successfully demonstrated in one mill by end of year 3
Trash system successfully operating in 3 mills by end of project

actual.comment: The project has not initiated its activities with GEF resources yet. However, during the assessment of the situation it has been verified that the work on the first mill with co-financing from MCTI has been satisfactorily undertaken at Alta Mogiana Mill. A visit was made in order to formalize a cooperation agreement between CTBE and the mill through the project duration. Besides, in order to update the trash system baseline, it was started an evaluation of the state of art at the mill. Additionally, Usina da Pedra Mill and Raízen Group demonstrated interest in participating of the project. All the three sent representatives to the Inception Workshop, and their participation with explanation of the activities being conducted in terms of trash experiments confirmed their willingness to proceed investing to increase electricity generation with trash, as far as technology and barriers can be properly addressed.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Increase in exports of biomass based electricity to the grid

baseline.comment: Electricity exports by mills limited to excess generation from sugarcane bagasse; no additional generation using sugarcane trash in place

target.comment:
70% increase in electricity exports from mills that implemented the trash system
60,000 MWh/yr exported to the grid by mill 1 at end of yr 3
180,000 MWh/yr exported to the grid by mills 1, 2, and 3 at end of project

actual.comment: This specific task has not been initiated yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Economic feasibility of increased generation with trash is demonstrated

baseline.comment: Electricity sales are a limited operation in sugarcane mills

target.comment:
Increased revenues from additional electricity generation demonstrated in 3 mills
The share of revenues from electricity generation increases in proportion to sugar and ethanol in 3 mills

actual.comment: No intervention has been made yet as an action of the Project to increase power generation by the mills. Present exports of electricity by the partner mills are being determined to serve as a baseline.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Trash system replicated across the sugar sector

baseline.comment: No mills or distilleries are using the trash produced by the green harvesting

target.comment:
Investment leveraged for installation of trash system in at least one additional mill by end of project
Trash system feasibility studies for 7 other mills

actual.comment: This specific task has not been initiated yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Environmental and legal framework in place for electricity generation with bagasse

baseline.comment: Environmental and regulatory conditions for increased generation with sugarcane trash not fully defined

target.comment:
Clear, streamlined environmental guidelines and procedures for generation with sugarcane trash
Well defined regulatory framework for generation with sugarcane trash

actual.comment: This specific task has not been initiated yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Information disseminated on project results and the benefits of additional generation with sugarcane trash

baseline.comment: Limited information available on potential benefits of sugarcane trash use for electricity generation

target.comment: Clear guidelines, procedures, and demonstrated benefits of generation with sugarcane trash are published and widely disseminated across the sugarcane sector in Brazil and internationally.

actual.comment: Dissemination area of the Project is being structured.

result.title: Outcome 1

indicator.description: Trash collection system design finalized and operational

No methodology to define trash to be collected in place

Methodology defined and being used
Final design implemented and operational in mill #1

baseline.comment: Limited information on economic and financial viability in place, based on existing R&D

target.comment: Full feasibility studies and business plans finalized for mills 1, 2, and 3

actual.comment: Some of the partners’ mills are already recovering trash as a pilot activity. Discussions on how to collect and organize this data have already started.

indicator.description: Economic/financial performance of mills #1, #2, and #3 evaluated based on actual operating data and costs.

baseline.comment:
No trash-electricity system available
Electricity exports from mills limited to excess energy generated with sugarcane bagasse without trash

target.comment:
Economic feasibility demonstrated for use of trash to make exportable electricity at mills #1, #2, and #3.
70 % increase in sale of electricity at mills #1, #2, and #3 due to inclusion of additional sugarcane trash

actual.comment: This specific task has not been initiated yet.

result.description: Environmental integrity of the use of biomass for energy is assured.

indicator.description: Guidelines for environmentally acceptable trash utilization completed and distributed

Quantitative understanding of potential net GHG reductions from use of trash for electricity generation.
Sector wide analysis of CDM potential for enhanced trash use.

actual.comment: This specific task has not been initiated yet.

Specific assessment conducted to demonstrate the potential impacts on deforestation
Mitigation strategy developed and under implementation

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Dissemination, capacity building, replication strategy across the sugar cane sector is under implementation.

Guidelines for general pre-feasibility assessment of trash utilization
Feasibility studies for 7 mills (beyond the first three) completed

indicator.title: Indicator 5

No trash system in place in additional mills
No investors interested

actual.comment: The Project is raising the interest of the sugarcane sector, and the selection of these additional 7 mills might happen even before the implementation of the first 3 mills.

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: Institutional, legal, regulatory framework is in place to promote the sustainable use of biomass for electricity generation and sales to the grid.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Mutually beneficial regulations fostering increased electricity generation with sugarcane trash are implemented

baseline.comment: Current legislation favorable to IPP generation but does not consider technicalities of generation with bagasse

target.comment:
Full knowledge of relevant legislation regulating the electricity sector in Brazil is obtained, including potential solutions to address remaining barriers for generation with trash
Meetings conducted with relevant state entities to discuss new regulatory framework that addresses sugarcane industry trash-to-electricity issues and barriers
Mutually beneficial regulatory reforms agreed between regulating entities and the sugar sector

actual.comment: A meeting with UNICA has already been conducted confirming that the entity will continue to support the Project, and that the need to address these regulatory aspects is a must. UNICA also confirmed that a “Cogeneration Group” with UNICA’s participation and representatives of several mills meets at regular period to discuss these barriers and is an important forum for debates and to organize contacts with Government.

result.title: Outcome 6
result.description: Project monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation

Internal monitoring procedure described in project document
Project document reflects current understanding of best project strategy

target.comment:
Internal monitoring procedures implemented with at least two project reports generated per year
Project implementation strategy is strengthened by continuous integration of lessons learnt during implementation

actual.comment: Monitoring and evaluation needs have been detailed by UNDP and a strategy for the implementation of these procedures have started to be discussed with UNDP.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: High quality external evaluations are conducted

baseline.comment: No evaluations conducted

target.comment: One Mid Term evaluation and One Final Evaluation conducted

actual.comment: Project just started and no external evaluation has been performed yet. This matter will be discussed with UNDP to previously define when and who will perform this evaluation.

indicator.title: Output Indicator

baseline.comment: 1. No standards for environmental management of ILs. 2. Very limited resources used for environmental management of ILs (1 or 2 pilot experiences throughout the country). 3. No capacity for implementation of norms and regulations for ethno-management and ethno-zoning in ILs (<20% of MMA staff and <15% of FUNAI with some knowledge of BD conservation and use in ILs).

target.comment: 1. Regular meetings of SC with PNGATI Conferences taking place. 2. An Intergrated Plan for implementation of PNGATI for PPA 2016-2019 prepared for financing of land and environmental management plans in ILs. 3. Capacity building initiatives undertaken in order to train IPs and staff in MMA, IBAMA, ICMBio, FUNAI, among others, in order to implement and follow specific norms and regulations for ethno-management and ethno-zoning in ILs.

result.title: Objective
result.description: A ground-tested and officially recognized strategy for environmental management in Indigenous Lands (IL) by Indigenous Peoples (IP) is adopted in Brazil for the effective conservation and sustainable use of forest biodiversity

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Increase in the area (ha.) of representative forest ecosystems of Brazil under conservation through the recognized environmental goals of ILs that by the end of the project are:
(i) incorporated into a network of ethno-management practices for conservation of different forest ecosystems in Brazil; ILs (ha) in network with recognized BD goals
(ii) identified as contributing to long term targets of PNAP and part of IL Environmental Management Plan with specific strategies for implementation; ILs (ha) in long term plans

baseline.comment: 1. Currently ILs in different forest biomes provide conservation to forest biodiversity but the contribution to national conservation plans and targets is not measured nor are the IPs management practices readily translated into terms that can be recognized and funded through resources available for biodiversity conservation. The potential for contribution to Brazilâ€™ conservation goals is thus not fully recognized.

actual.comment: The PNGATI Steering Committee, installed on Oct. 30, 2013, has since met several times. During the 2nd CG PNGATI Ordinary Meeting, on 03/25 - 26/2014, two Technical Councils were created: one to organize the PNGATI National Conference and the other to create the Integrated Plan for PNGATI implementation (PIPNGATI). The latter promoted a workshop on 11/20 - 21/2014 to create a logical framework for implementation of the Policy. This framework will be used by the different ministries to orient the federal government´s Pluriannual Plan for 2016-2019, currently being constructed by the Ministry of Planning and Budget. And during the 4th Ordinary Meeting (12/02-21/03/2014), the CG PNGATI discussed the planning framework proposal and defined a timeline for ordinary meetings in 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Test

baseline.comment: Test

target.comment:
see cells below
% # ILs in network | % ha in network | % ha IL in plan

actual.comment: The PNGATI Steering committee has drafted an Integrated plan for policy implementation, This framework will be used by the different ministries to orient the federal government´s Pluriannual Plan for 2016-2019, currently being constructed by the Ministry of Planning and Budget, with the idea of creating synergy between the actions of the different ministries

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Cerrrado/P.

actual.comment: According to the Permanent Interministerial Working Group PPCerrado´s 2nd Phase Report (2014-2015), the 95 Indigenous Lands in the Cerrado Biome continue to show very low rates of deforestation, on the order of 4% of their total area (slightly more than 90,000 km2). This compares very favorably with the rate for conservation areas (22%) and agricultural settlements (40%) and clearly demonstrates the effectivity of ILs in conserving biodiversity of the Cerrado, Brazil´s second largest biome.

indicator.description: Caatinga

actual.comment: Through partnership with TNC, an alternative instrument to measure management effectiveness in ILs was created. This instrument was presented and improved in a workshop held in October 2014, at Funai in Brasília. The improved version was applied in Oiapoque ILs, with very positive results, including the perception of its usefulness by the village leaders involved in its application.

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description:
4. Increase in IP capacities for leading and up-scaling environmental management actions for conserving representative forest ecosystems in Brazil
IOs, with institutional &technical capacities to execute & monitor IL National Plans & projects
Indigenous initiatives/centres for training in environmental management for BD conservation & sustainable use of natural resources

baseline.comment:
Today COIAB, FOIRN and CIR have institutional capacity for the execution of ethno-management and ethno-zoning plans. None has the capacity to execute a national plan of environmental management.
A Centre for Indigenous training exists in the Amazon CAFI and in 2006 trained 15 IPs in environmental management but this does not include standards and practices for ethno-zoning for BD conservation. Other regions do not have Centres or trained IPs

target.comment:
All IO of the 5 regional networks have strengthened capacities* for environmental management and to execute & monitor IL National Plans & projects.
20 IP in each of the biomes have skill required for ethno-environmental management

actual.comment:
The itinerant training program Mosarambihara (Seeders) for the Guarani-Kaiowá of 3 reference areas in Mato Grosso do Sul, held its first course module in December 2014. The indigenous organization ASCURI has been hired by means of a Letter of Agreement to carry out the remaining modules and register the course in video.
The proposed course in Agroecology for the Terena with the Universidade Estadual do Mato Grosso do Sul (UEMS), Glória de Dourados campus, has been shifted from a techical degree to a full undergraduate degree. University personnel and indigenous representatives will meet with the Ministry of Education in Brasília on July 1, 2015, for further discussion as to funding mechanisms for this proposal.
Through an agreement with the Instituto Sociedade, População e Natureza (ISPN), indigenous organizations in project reference areas presented proposals to a small grants program funded by the project, with 37 proposals approved (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=e236a7b66e&e=4a987eb951)

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Mechanisms and tools have been developed that enable Brazilâ€™s ILs to be recognized and strengthened as effective areas for conserving forest biodiversity, natural resources and the environmental services

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 5.Existence of recognized environmental management standards and targets in Indigenous Lands

baseline.comment:
A National Protected Areas Plan (PNAP) exists to guide the establishment of a comprehensive system of protected areas including contributions from ILs s but no specific targets, standards or practices for these are defined.
In Sept 2008, a working group (GTI) was established to elaborate a proposal of National Policy for Environmental Management in IL

target.comment:
A National Conservation Plan for Indigenous Lands that contains targets for conservation of representative forest ecosystems through environmental management * exists and is harmonized and integrated with the NPAP and adapted to the environmental and social needs of ILs
[*this Plan would be aligned with and form part of a National Policy on Environmental Management of IL (PNGATI)]

actual.comment: The PNGATI Steering Committee, installed on Oct. 30, 2013, has since met several times. During the 2nd CG PNGATI Ordinary Meeting, on 03/25 - 26/2014, two Technical Councils were created: one to organize the PNGATI National Conference and the other to create the Integrated Plan for PNGATI implementation (PIIPNGATI). The latter promoted a workshop on 11/20 - 21/2014 to create a logical framework for implementation of the Policy. This framework will be used by the different ministries to orient the federal government´s Pluriannual Plan for 2016-2019, currently being constructed by the Ministry of Planning and Budget. And during the 4th Ordinary Meeting (12/02-21/03/2014), the CG PNGATI discussed the planning framework proposal and defined a timeline for ordinary meetings in 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 6. Resources from existing biodiversity conservation sources used to achieve basic operating standards for environmental management in ILs

baseline.comment:
ILs currently do not receive funding for environmental management activities from public funding sources for biodiversity conservation.
Isolated support from NGOs to undertake environmental management and/or territorial surveillance activities in the ILs of Oiapoque, AmapÃ¡ and KayapÃ³

target.comment:
At least 5 of the Reference ILs will receive at least 50% of the costs of basic operations* from new funding mechanisms that include resources currently only available for biodiversity conservation in PA. environmental services compensation
[*The project will work to determine costs of meeting basic operational standards and will test different funding mechanisms.]

actual.comment:
The project assisted in the establishment of a new technical cooperation project (BRA/13/019) between Funai and UNDP, signed in December 2013, to help implement PNGATI and apply resources from the Fundo Clima/MMA-Ministério do Meio Ambiente, The project assisted in drafting the public call for proposal for ethnomanagement plans (PGTAs) in the Caatinga and Cerrado biomes (R$ 2.8 million), launched in August 2014. O f the 15 proposals selected, 4 are project reference areas, and were written with the help of project consultants. Through a Letter of Agreement with the Instituto Sociedade, População e Natureza (ISPN) the project is assisting in the initial training of the organizations carrying out the proposals.
The project assisted Funai and MMA in drafting the Fundo Amazonia/BNDES call for PGTA proposals - R$ 70 million (published in 08 May 2014) and helped the Andirá-Marau IL, a reference area, to prepare its proposal, in partnership with the Centro de Trabalho Indigenista (CTI). The proposal was approved, along with a proposal by CPI/Acre, which will benefit Mamoadate IL, another reference area.
Project partner TNC also approved a project with the Fundo Amazônia, in an earlier call for projects, for implementation of ethnomanagement plans in the reference areas where it is currently working (Amapá and Pará states) (R$ 15 million).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 7. Staff competencies and skills in MMA, IBAMA, ICMBio, FUNAI, OEMAs and/or municipal agencies) aligned to implement and follow specific norms and regulations for ethno-management and ethno-zoning in ILs.

baseline.comment: see data below

target.comment: see data below

actual.comment:
The PNGATI training course held at Acadebio (Academia Nacional da Biodiversidade) for the Mata Atlantica Biome, a joint effort of Funai, MMA/ICMBio and the project held the last of its 5 modules in November, 2014.
The training course in PNGATI for the Northeast region, MG and ES, with 5 itinerant modules, 4 of which were in or nearby project reference areas (with visits, in the latter cases), held its last module in May 2015, with an optional visit to the Cavernas de Peruaçu National Park, arranged by an ICMBio employee who participated in the course.
A similar training course for the Cerrado biome held its first module in Brasília, in June 2015, with a MMA employee participating.

baseline.comment: ·  <20% of MMA/SBF trained on ethno-management and ethno-zoning plans for Ils

target.comment: ·  At least 20% increase in the number of MMA and FUNAI staff trained to implement and use such norms

actual.comment: See above

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: See above

baseline.comment: ·  <15% of FUNAI has core groups of staff trained on environmental management and sustainable use activities in IL

target.comment: ·  At least 1 staff member in the OEMAs of the states of SC, MS, BA, PE, AM, PA, AC and RO trained to monitor these norms and regulations

actual.comment: See above

baseline.comment: ·  OEMAs do not have staff trained on environmental activities in Ils

target.comment: ·  IBAMA and ICMBio

actual.comment: A limited number of OEMA staff have participated in the PNGATI courses. The PNGATI Cerrado course, organized and funded by Funai, held its first module in June, 2015, has among its participantes an employee of Naturatins, the environmental agency for the state of Tocantins.

baseline.comment: ·  IBAMA and ICMBio

target.comment: ·  Competency profiles for MMA/SF and FUNAI have been adjusted to include IL/IP and biodiversity conservation respectively

actual.comment: ICMBio employees participated in the PNGATI training courses, one of which took place at the ICMBio ´s Academia Nacional da Biodiversidade (Acadebio). Three ICMBio employees participated in the Northeast, Minas Gerais e Espirito Santo PNGATI training course. Participation in the PNGATI courses has contributed to change in the paradigms held by ICMBio employees. As cited previously, ICMBio employees in the courses have begun to regard indigenous peoples as partners in conservation, especially important in cases of overlap between ILs and conservation areas. This was clearly stated in a letter addressed to the incoming president of ICMBio at the end of May 2015, and signed by more than 300 employees, the greater portion of whom are managers of conservation areas (Letter attached).

baseline.comment: ·  Staff requirements in MMA/SBF and FUNAI do not include profiles for IL/IP and biodiversity conservation respectively

target.comment: ·  Staff requirements in MMA/SBF and FUNAI include profiles for IL/IP and biodiversity conservation respectively

actual.comment: Funai employees are participating in all the PNGATI training courses. The PNGATI Cerrado course is being organized and funded by Funai, and held its first module in June, 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description:
8. Regulations adopted for environmental management in ILs including regulations on:
ethno zoning in ILs
land-use in areas surrounding ILs
management of overlapping IL and UCs
sustainable use of forest resources of IL

target.comment:
At least 3 categories of ethno-zoning recognized for: conservation, sustainable use and restoration.
At least 1 regulation regarding land-use in the areas surrounding ILs e.g creation of IL buffers zones
Norms on homologizing management plans and ethno-plans of IL and UC
Agreed-upon standards and limits for use of forest resources

actual.comment: The joint Working Group on IL and conservation area overlap presented a report of its activities, mapping all instances of overlap.

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: 9. Existence of surveillance and monitoring plans with standards and practices defined to support the implementation of ethno zoning and plans

baseline.comment:
Only ILs that were part of PPTAL in the Amazon have surveillance and monitoring protocols and carry out inspection activities in ILs but these do not contain environmental monitoring nor are they related to specific ethno- zones and their goals
ILs in other forest biomes do not have surveillance and monitoring protocols and only have Indigenous Surveillance (observation) Stations that are not related to zoning

target.comment:
All the IL reference areas have established surveillance Protocols and undertaken environmental monitoring
50% of the ILs composing the network have established Surveillance Protocols and are developing environmental monitoring systems

actual.comment: Although no new specific regulations have been created, monitoring and surveillance of ILs is an ongoing activity for Funai, in colaboration with Ibama.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: A network of ILs modeling environmental management practices for conservation in different forest biomes is in place and is being effectively managed by the indigenous peoples and organizations

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 10. Number of ethno-management plans in ILs that are:

baseline.comment: see data below

target.comment: see data below

actual.comment:
Through a letter of agreement with Anai-Bahia, ethnomanagement plans were developed for the reference areas Entre Serras and Caiçara/Ilha de São Pedro (Northeast Region). These were presented during a three-day seminar held in Paulo Afonso (Bahia), April 7-10, 2015 (see http://us3.campaign-archive1.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=71b7f2feba&e=4a987eb951). At the present moment, therefore, 8 of the project reference areas have ethnomanagement plans completed (Mamoadate, Igarapé Lourdes, Wajãpi, Galibi, Jumina, Uaçá ILs already had ethnomanagement plans).
The project surveyed gray literature and other sources, identifying another 45 existing ethnomanagement plans in other ILs (as well as a few other plans that cover a portion of an IL).
The project assisted Funai in establishing a new technical cooperation project with UNDP (BRA/13/019) to help implement PNGATI and apply resources from the Fundo Clima/MMA-Ministério do Meio Ambiente, The project assisted in drafting the public call for proposasl for ethnomanagement plans (PGTAs) in the Caatinga and Cerrado biomes (R$ 2.8 million), launched in August 2014. Of the 15 proposals selected, 4 are project reference areas (Bakairi, Xerente, Xacriabá and Corrego João Pereira ILs), and were written with the help of project consultants. Through a Letter of Agreement with the Instituto Sociedade, População e Natureza (ISPN) the project assisted in the initial training of the organizations carrying out the proposals (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=65d3e8bace&e=4a987eb951).
Also with the assistance of ISPN, the project launched a call for small projects in the reference areas, and Taunay-Ipegue IL approved a project for ethnomapping.
Project consultants are carrying out ethnomapping workshops in Bracui IL (Rio de Janeiro) as part of an ethnomanagement plan. In Mangueirinha IL (Paraná), the project held a three-day workshop to discuss ethnomanagement, including one day of ethnomapping (see http://us3.campaign-archive1.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=e8a23d4715&e=4a987eb951).
Through partnership with TNC, training of youths in ethnomapping was carried out in Trincheira-Bacajá IL.
The project signed a letter of agreement with the Comissão Pró-Índio/Acre to carry out the revision of Mamoadate IL´s ethnomanagement plan.
The basic tools of ethnomanagement, ethnomapping and ethnozoning, are being discussed in all the PNGATI training courses (see for example http://us3.campaign-archive1.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=502428d96a&e=4a987eb951)

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: developed and tested

baseline.comment: 5 communities in Oiapoque are testing environmental management strategies

target.comment: 10 tested ethno-management plan with defined sustainable use, conservation practices, zones and goals relevant for each of the four forest biomes

actual.comment:
The project assisted in the establishment of a new technical cooperation project (BRA/13/019) between Funai and UNDP, signed in December 2013, to help implement PNGATI and apply resources from the Fundo Clima/MMA-Ministério do Meio Ambiente, The project assisted in drafting the public call for proposal for ethnomanagement plans (PGTAs) in the Caatinga and Cerrado biomes (R$ 2.8 million), launched in August 2014. Of the 15 proposals selected, 4 are project reference areas (Bakairi, Xerente, Xacriabá and Corrego João Pereira ILs), and were written with the help of project consultants. Through a Letter of Agreement with the Instituto Sociedade, População e Natureza (ISPN) the project is assisting in the initial training of the organizations carrying out the proposals (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=65d3e8bace&e=4a987eb951)
The project assisted Funai and MMA in drafting the Fundo Amazonia/BNDES call for PGTA proposals - R$ 70 million (published in 08 May 2014) and helped the Andirá-Marau IL, a reference area, to prepare its proposal, in partnership with the Centro de Trabalho Indigenista (CTI). The proposal was approved, along with a proposal by CPI/Acre, which will benefit Mamoadate IL, another reference area.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: have defined conservation goals

target.comment: 30 more ILs developing ethno management plans

actual.comment: See above

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: are officially recognized as meeting established norms for conservation by environmental and indigenous agencies in each regional

baseline.comment: Today about 60% of the RAs have conserved areas but their contribution to biodiversity conservation is not measure not recognized officially by relevant institutions ( eg FUNAI and IBAMA/OEMAS)

target.comment: All plans in reference areas are officially recognized as meeting norms by environmental agencies in each region

actual.comment: Although there is no legal instrument that officially recognizes PGTAs, they are increasingly being used as instruments for public policy in regards to indigenous lands and in situations where they may be a part of environmental/social mitigation and compensation programs.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 11. Degree of replication of experiences from Reference Areas to other ILs that improve management effectiveness as measured by increase in the METT scores of a sample of 23 ILS

baseline.comment:
METT for a sample of 23 ILs:
Poor: 0
Fair: 9
Good: 9
Excellent: 5

target.comment:
All Poor and Fair have reached at least Good Scores
All Good have reached Excellent Scores
All Excellent have remained Excellent

actual.comment: Through a Letter of Agreement with project partner TNC, an alternative instrument was proposed and tested in a workshop in Brasília in Oct. 2014, This instrument is currently being applied in reference areas in the Oiapoque region (Amapá) with very positive results.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: 12. % of indigenous curricula that include information on BD & environmental management

baseline.comment: see data below

target.comment: see data below

actual.comment: As part of its final actions and products, the project is discussing a series of publications containing information on the biodiversity of the reference areas, as part of a strategy to produce information accessible to several target audiences, including schools.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: · IP schools in network

baseline.comment: · 0% of 30 (at least 1 per IL of network)

target.comment: · 50% of IP schools in network

actual.comment: See above

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: · IP schools nationwide

target.comment: · 10% IP schools across country

actual.comment: See above

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: IP training centers (CFI)

baseline.comment: 1 for the whole Amazon region.

target.comment: 100% of 5 CFI

actual.comment: Partner organization IEB, with support of the Moore Foundation, surveyed existing experiences with training of indigenous environmental agents in Amazonia, and held a seminar with representatives of these programs in April 2015. A national seminar, for which the project will bring representatives from other regions, is planned for the second semester 2015.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Sustainable and replicable models of forest management , based on ethno-management principles, are piloted in selected ILs from different forest biomes

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 13. Reduction in un-sustainable extractive practices in the RAs

baseline.comment: The base line values will be established by ethno-zoning and ethno-management plans

target.comment: 100% reduction in the caatinga, cerrado and Atlantic forest biomes, in the Amazon biome

actual.comment:
Ibirama IL (SC) approved a small project to produce of seedlings of the jussara palm (Euterpe edulis) for replanting in areas where this species has been decimated by extraction of palm hearts, building on and expanding the microproject.
In Mangueirinha IL (Paraná), indigenous leaders expressed concern with harvesting levels of erva maté and other forest products, and suggested carrying out an inventory of these resources. The project brought leaders to Brasília to discuss inclusion of Mangueirinha IL in the National Forest Inventory, carried out by the Serviço Florestal Brasileiro with GEF funding, through FAO (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=c20c4bfa0c&e=4a987eb951)

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 14. Increase in the % of IP diet derived from the new agro-ecological production systems in ILs Reference Areas in the Caatinga, Cerrado and A.F

baseline.comment:
IPs in Amazon get food from in the IL.
IPs diet in Cerrado and the Atlantic Forest comes from locally grown crops and food bought in regional markets
IPs in Caatinga grow and gather food in IL, exerting high pressure on the few resources available
[Base line values will be established by ethno-zoning & ethno-management plans]

target.comment: Community inside IL subsist with production derived from agro-ecological production within the zones delimited for this use

actual.comment:
Through a letter of agreement, the Centro de Desenvolvimento Agroecologico Sabia, carried out agroecological and agroforestry extension in 3 reference areas in the Northeast region, training youths as multipliers (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=29a8d98645&e=4a987eb951)
In collaboration with the Projeto Warana Agroecologia, the project helped organize the 1st Fair of Seeds, Flavors and Knowledge in the Andirá-Marau IL (Amazonas). See:http://us3.campaign-archive1.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=5bee8f2c3f&e=4a987eb951
The project is currently supporting an 8-module extension course in Agroecology with the three Terena reference areas in Mato Grosso do Sul (Cachoeirinha, Lalima and Taunay/Ipegue), in collaboration with the Universidade Estadual do Mato Grosso do Sul - Campus Glória de Dourados. The first module was held in June 2015, and the following modules will be held in the second semester of 2015.
Through an agreement with the Instituto Sociedade, População e Natureza (ISPN), indigenous organizations in project reference areas presented proposals to a small grants program, with 37 proposals approved (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=e236a7b66e&e=4a987eb951). A number of the projects have agroecology as their focus.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
15. Increase in the income derived from the trade of NTFP, including:
Honey (melipona)
Fruit: Cashew, aÃ§aÃ­, baru
Handicraft: liana, croÃ¡

baseline.comment:
Note: The exact value of the income will be measured by end of year 1
Acai - R$9.6-/1 lt conc
Native Bee Honey - R$18.50/235g
Babacu soap - R$2.00/90g
Baru nut toasted - R$12.00/200g
Capim Dourado bag - R$56/19x13x7cm
Caainga Croa - R$20.00/1m^2

target.comment:
ILs in Cerrado, Caatinga, and Atlantic Forest with at least one income-generating agro-ecological activity
In the Amazon, 3 of the 4 RAs with trading activities implemented

actual.comment: Through an agreement with the Instituto Sociedade, População e Natureza (ISPN), indigenous organizations in project reference areas presented proposals to a small grants program, with 37 proposals approved (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=e236a7b66e&e=4a987eb951). A number of the projects have extractive production as their focus.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 16. Area of fragmented forest restored in IL of A. forest with native species to improve connectivity

baseline.comment: The base line values will be established by ethno-zoning and ethno-management plans

target.comment: At least 40% of the fragmented areas that are critical to connectivity are in the process of restoration with native species

actual.comment:
Through an agreement with the Instituto Sociedade, População e Natureza (ISPN), indigenous organizations in project reference areas presented proposals to a small grants program, with 37 proposals approved (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=e236a7b66e&e=4a987eb951). A number of the projects have agroforestry and landscape recuperation as their focus.
In the Potiguara IL, a number of small-scale initiatives for reforestation are underway, funded by microprojects and with technical assistance provided through the Letter of Agreement with the Centro Sabiá. Through these initiatives, an estimated 64 hectares have been planted.
The project has drafted a technical document summarizing the potential contribution of ILs, by means of initiatives of environmental restoration, to help Brasil meet its goals of forest restoration and carbon sequestration that it has assumed in international conventions or agreements such as Aichi or the Bonn Challenge (document with executive summary in English is attached).

result.title: Objective
result.description: To assist the Government of Brazil to perform the activities necessary to prepare the Third National Communication to the Conference of Parties in accordance with the UNFCCC.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: (A) National GHG inventory for the sectors: (i) energy; (ii) industry; (iii) agriculture; (iv) LULUCF; and (v) waste for 2000-2010 produced; and time-series 1990-2000 refined;

baseline.comment: (A) SNC;

target.comment: (A) TNC;

actual.comment: The National GHG Inventory for the sectors (i), (ii), (iii), (iv) and (v) was done for 2000-2010 and also refined for 1990-2000 period. At this moment, the Brazilian government is evaluating the inventory results for approval.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: (B) Publication of formal communication on national circumstances to the UNFCCC;

baseline.comment: (B) SNC;

target.comment: (B) TNC;

actual.comment: All information about National Circumstances and modelling studies was revised by MCTI's technical team. At this moment, the complete document is being evaluated by the Brazilian government to approve the submission to UNFCCC.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: (C) Publication of Third National Communication;

baseline.comment: (C) SNC;

target.comment: (C) TNC;

actual.comment: The sector responsible for institutional communications is supporting the activities needed to TNC publication. Moreover, the translation of the document has been already started and the bidding process for the graphic service is in course.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: (D) Building institutional capacity in Brazil for education, training and public awareness related to climate change.

baseline.comment: (C) SNC;

target.comment: (D) TNC.

actual.comment: The Rede CLIMA has been playing an important role through the participation in discussions regarding climate modelling activities and emission factors for the GHG Inventory. All these activities have also been responsible for the consolidation of this network as a pivotal partner of the implementation of the UNFCCC in Brazil. Moreover, the TNC document was available for the public consultation, from October 2014 to January 2015, with the involvement of experts and representatives of civil society. To strengthen the institutional capacity building for education, training and public awareness related to climate change, it is planned for next months to hold a workshop to release and discuss the results presented in TNC.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: The national GHG inventory 2000-2010 has been produced and time-series 1990-2000 have been refined for key emission sectors.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: (A) National GHG inventory for the sectors: (i) energy; (ii) industry; (iii) agriculture; (iv) LULUCF; and (v) waste; for 2000-2010 produced and time-series 1990-2000 refined.

baseline.comment: (A) GHG inventory available for period 1990-1994 (FNC) and 1990-2000 (SNC);

target.comment: (A) GHG inventory available for the period 1990-2010, including refinement of time-series 1990-2000;

actual.comment: The preparation of the National GHG Inventory for the sectors (i), (ii), (iii), (iv) and (v) is finished. At this moment, the Brazilian government is evaluating the document for approval.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: (B) QA/QC plan for GHG emission data per sector;

baseline.comment: (B) QA/QC pilot has been designed and implemented under SNC;

target.comment: (B) Analysis of key GHG emission categories and uncertainty analysis available, and a QA/QC plan established;

actual.comment: The emission categories and uncertainty analysis were finished. Moreover, the experts of Rede CLIMA have evaluated the quality of data and methodological aspects.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: (C) Database of emission factors and activity data.;

baseline.comment: (C) Pilot database available under the SNC;

target.comment: (C) Data base of emission factors available.

actual.comment: The development of the simplified database platform was finalized and, at this moment, it is in a validation phase by the technical team of MCTI.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: National circumstances, steps taken or envisaged, constraints and needs have been assessed as input for the implementation of the UNFCCC in Brazil.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: (A) Assessment of national circumstances in Brazil;;

baseline.comment: (A) SNC (data until 2005);

target.comment: (A) TNC (data until 2013);

actual.comment: All information made available by several governmental institutions was compiled in a single domcument and reviewed by several governmental parties. At the moment the Document is under evaluation by the GoB.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: (B) Assessment of constraints and needs to implement the Convention in Brazil;

baseline.comment: (B) SNC (data until 2005);

target.comment: (B) TNC (data until 2013);

actual.comment: All information made available by several governmental institutions was compiled in a single domcument and reviewed by several governmental parties. At the moment the Document is under evaluation by the GoB.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: (C) Identification of activities and CC measures to implement the Convention in Brazil;

baseline.comment: (C) SNC (data until 2005);

target.comment: (C) TNC (data until 2013);

actual.comment: All information made available by several governmental institutions was compiled in a single domcument and reviewed by several governmental parties. At the moment the Document is under evaluation by the GoB.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: (D) Publication of formal communication on national circumstances to the UNFCCC;

baseline.comment: (D) SNC (preliminary SNC results made public by April 2010);

target.comment: (D) TNC (preliminary TNC results made public by April 2013).

actual.comment: All information made available by several governmental institutions was compiled in a single domcument and reviewed by several governmental parties. At the moment the Document is under evaluation by the GoB.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Sector and regional vulnerabilities to climate change have been assessed using improved methodologies and climate models.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: (A) Status of â€œBrazilian Global Model of the Climate System (MBSCG);

baseline.comment: (A) SNC (no Brazilian Global model, only Eta/CPTEC regional model);

target.comment: (A) MBSCG developed and Eta/CPTEC model improved with higher resolution for a larger domain;

actual.comment:
The Global Model of the Climate System (MBSCG) and the Eta/CPTEC regional model were improved with higher resolution for a larger domain. The coupled ocean-atmosphere version of the Brazilian Earth System Model (BESM) - former MBSCG - was implemented and tested in the supercomputer Tupa, installed at INPE. This version of BESM is able to generate scenarios of global climate change for present time up to 2100.
However, a preliminary analysis, identified the need for improvements in some used models. Now it is necessary to investigate these gaps and needs more accurately, a process that will now rely on the recent entry of Brazil in the Earth System Grid Federation (ESGF) through INPE.
In order to enhance the country’s data assessment and management capacities, which are critical to facilitate BESM’s developing process, after a comprehensive survey, INPE proposed that the Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation of Brazil (MCTI) financed the Institute’s insertion in the Earth System Grid Federation (ESGF), a ultra-scale data network that provides state-of-the-art online communication for the exchange of information among specialists that are contributing to BESM’s completion.
Thus, along with the acquisition of the equipment and software required to make Brazil one of the ESGF world nods, a specialist was hired to design and present workshops aimed at training INPE and other institutions’ researchers and public managers in this new tool. Currently, INPE resarchers are already using the ESGF-INPE platform and the second workshop is being planned by the consultant and the TCN’s Coordination team.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: (B) Detailed climate change scenarios based on MBSCG and regional Eta model;

baseline.comment: (B) Limited climate change scenarios generated under SNC;

target.comment: (B) Higher number (at least 4) climate change scenarios generated under TNC;

actual.comment: Climate scenarios for the next 100 years, based on the RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5 and HadGEM scenarios, generated by BESM and used by the IPCC in its AR5, prepared by experts in climate modeling of the Rede CLIMA.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: (C) Climate change impact assessment for key sectors (agriculture, water resources, energy, megacities and urban areas, biodiversity, human health);

baseline.comment: (C) Limited CC impact assessment has been prepared under SNC;

target.comment: (C) Improved CC impact assessment has been prepared under TNC;

actual.comment: All Terms of Reference prepared by Rede CLIMA sub-networks supported the hiring of consultants who worked under each sub-network coordination analysing data generated through the scenario. The reports were evaluated by INPE senior researchers and compiled into a single document describing each sectorial vulnerabilities.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: (D) Mapping of vulnerability of key sectors and regions to climate change impacts.

baseline.comment: (D) Inadequate insight in key V&A sectors due to limitations of data and methodologies under SNC.

target.comment: (D) Improved insight in key V&A sectors due to improved data and methodologies under TNC.

actual.comment: All Terms of Reference prepared by Rede CLIMA sub-networks supported the hiring of consultants who worked under each sub-network coordination analysing data generated through the scenario. The reports were evaluated by INPE senior researchers and compiled into a single document describing each sectorial vulnerabilities.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: The Brazilian Third National Communication has been published and presented to the Government and national stakeholders.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: (A) Sharing of project outputs (reports, GHG inventories, website);

baseline.comment: (A) Project outputs not produced;

target.comment: (A) Project reports, GHG inventories and website updated and published;

actual.comment: The team of experts and consultants involved in the Third National Communication has been mobilized in order to define, along with the MCTI press office, the activities that will result in the publication in different media of all outputs contained in the TNC. Data platform for the GHG Inventory was finished and it is in validation and test stage.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: (B) Publication of Third National Communication;

baseline.comment: (B) Preliminary SNC results made public (April 2010);

target.comment: (B) TNC has been finalized and presented to the GoB;

actual.comment: The sector responsible for institutional communications is supporting the activities needed to TCN publication. Moreover, the translation of the document has been already started and the bidding process for the graphic service is in course.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: (C) Final Evaluation Report.

baseline.comment: (C) No FEV.

target.comment: (C) FEV completed.

actual.comment: A final report of each work is going to be prepared jointly with both Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation and Rede CLIMA. This report will cover all aspects (positive and negative) of the activities leading to the preparation of the TNC. The independent final evaluation is being hired by UNDP.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. número de documentos de diagnósticos, estudos e pesquisas elaborados.

target.comment: 1. Elaboração de 72 documentos com a definição de metodologia, diretrizes e referências para orientar a prestação de serviços e suporte técnico para os processos de qualificação de técnicos e agentes de ATER. 2. Elaboração de 72 documentos técnicos contendo estratégias setoriais e locais, configurações de instrumentos de apoio, mecanismos de acesso a mercados e outros voltados para a organização da base produtiva. 3. Realização de 42 estudos técnicos contendo caracterização de biomas, mecanismos e instrumentos de combate ás mudanças climáticas, métodos e tecnologias para a sustentabilidade da produção. 4. Realização de 96 documentos para referenciar e desenvolver metodologias e instrumentos para os processos de monitoramento e avaliação das políticas e programas para a agricultura familiar e implantação do observatório.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.1 - Análises executivas dos Objetivos de Desenvolvimento do Milênio produzidos anualmente por cada Estado da Federação. 1.2 - Relatórios Regionais de Acompanhamento dos ODM produzidos, em parceria com instituições de pesquisa e conhecimento. 1.3 - Portal ODM aperfeiçoado e fortalecido. 1.4 - Relatório de Desenvolvimento Humano, com cálculo do IDH Municipal e dados do Censo 2010, produzido. 1.5 - Práticas premiadas desde a primeira edição do Prêmio ODM monitoradas. 2.1 - Gestão municipal para o alcance dos ODM fortalecida. 2.2 - Capacidade dos Núcleos Estaduais de ODM desenvolvidas e fortalecidas para capacitar, mobilizar e dinamizar a agenda dos ODM. 2.3 - Prêmio ODM Brasil. 4ª Edição 2011; 5ª Edição 2012; 6ª Edição 2013 e 7ª Edição em 2014 realizados. 2.4 - Conferência Nacional sobre os ODM de 2013 realizada. 2.5 - Parcerias com instituições da sociedade civil em prol dos ODM estabelecidas e/ou fortalecidas. 2.6 - Parcerias com o Setor Privado e o Pacto Global estabelecidas. 2.7 - Estratégia de comunicação para sensibilização e promoção dos ODMs no Brasil desenvolvida. 3.1 - Governo Federal Ministérios e demais órgãos públicos federais sensibilizados e comprometidos com a promoção das políticas públicas articulada com o cumprimento dos ODM. 3.2 - ODM promovido de forma articulada com as políticas públicas do governo federal. 4.1 - Gestão eficiente do projeto desenvolvida .

baseline.comment: 1 - Produção de conhecimentos e experiências sobre os ODM sistematizadas e disseminadas. 2 - Setor público, sociedade civil e setor privado sensibilizados e comprometidos com os ODM de maneira localizada. 3 - Políticas públicas do Governo Federal fortalecidas, potencializadas e articuladas com o cumprimento dos ODM. 4 - Gestão eficiente e efetiva do Projeto.

target.comment: 1.1 - Análise de tema ODM indigena concluida e sistematizada (1 relatório, 1 oficina) 1.2 - Portal ODM atualizado com base em feedback de usuarios 1.4 - Atlasmetropolitano lançado e novas porpostas de adaptação da ferramenta em desenvolvimento 1.5 - Práticas premiadas desde a primeira edição do Prêmio ODM monitoradas 2.1 - Ferramentas para fortalecimento da gestão municipal em preparação para ODS em desenvolvinento 2.2 - Capacidade dos Núcleos Estaduais de ODM fortalecida com foco especial em prestação de contas e captação de recursos. 2.5 - Parcerias com instituições da sociedade civil em preparação para adoção dos ODS fortalecidas e estrategia de engajamento pos-2015 formulada 2.6 - Evento brasileiro relacionado a cupula da ONU concebido e implementado 2.6 - Proposta de plataforma Incluir e relatorio lançados 2.7 - Estratégia de comunicação para sensibilização e promoção dos ODS junto a sociedade civil no Brasil am desenvolvimento. 3.2. Governo Federal (SGPR) apoiada em divulgação da experiencia brasileira em municipalização e gestão intersetorial dos ODM 4.1 - Gestão eficiente do projeto desenvolvida e revisão substantiva do projeto estruturada 4.1. Auditoria independente incluindo anos 2013 e 2014 finalizada

result.title: Objective
result.description: Conservation of the Cerrado and Caatinga biomes of Brazil through community initiatives on sustainable resource use, and actions that maintain or enhance carbon stocks and increase areas under sustainable land management

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Increased area in production landscapes meeting sustainability standards
with enhanced biodiversity conservation
Increased area in production landscapes meeting sustainability standards
with enhanced biodiversity conservation

baseline.comment: 200,000 hectares managed sustainably as a result of SGP support in OP4

target.comment:
Additional 300,000 ha sustainably managed in the Cerrado ecosystem
100,000 ha in the Caatinga ecosystem
Sustainability criteria and standards developed and adapted to social and environmental conditions of Cerrado and Caatinga

actual.comment: 586,624 hectares under sustainable management in the Cerrado and 2,525.6 hectares of Caatinga

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Carbon stocks maintained or increased through maintenance and expansion of habitats

baseline.comment: Deforestation rate in the Caatinga biome is 276,300 ha/p.a and 1,418,000 ha/p.a in the Cerrado

target.comment:
500 hectares of Caatinga ecosystem restored, equivalent to 18,200 tCO2e sequestered
500 hectares of Cerrado ecosystem restored, equivalent to 37,400 tCO2e sequestered during life of project
80,000 hectares with avoided conversion to pasture or monoculture and environmental services maintained, equivalent to 4,370,400 tCO2e of emissions avoided during the life of the project

actual.comment:
558 hectares of Caatinga ecosystem being restored, equivalent to 2,623.1 tCO2e sequestered
481 hectares of Cerrado ecosystem being restored, equivalent to 29,112 tCO2e sequestered
73,605 hectares with avoided conversion to pasture or monoculture and environmental services maintained
Avoided emissions of 5,154,762 tCO2 equivalent.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Increased area of sustainable land management techniques that sustain the flow of environmental services in agro-ecosystems by communities supported by SGP

baseline.comment: 2200 ha (as a result of SGP support in OP 4)

target.comment:
An additional 200 hectares in Caatinga and 400 hectares in the Cerrado in which communities apply innovative soil management techniques
2,000 hectares with improved ecosystem services as a result of community adoption of innovative water management techniques

actual.comment:
2,570 hectares in which communities apply innovative soil management techniques
4,424 hectares with improved ecosystem services as a result of community adoption of innovative water management techniques

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Sustainable use and management of natural resources by communities to enhance conservation of biodiversity in the production landscape

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of sustainable land use plans or resource use plans developed, as well as plans for conservation of endangered species

baseline.comment: There are no existing plans in targeted communities

target.comment: 15 plans developed by stakeholders

actual.comment: There are three projects developing the management planning for their collective reserves: BRA/SGP/OP5/FSP/STAR/13/03; BRA/SGP/OP5/FSP/STAR/14/04 and BRA/SGP/OP5/FSP/STAR/14/14

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of native plant and animal species considered endangered or important for sustainable livelihoods conserved in-situ and sustainably used

baseline.comment: 29 endangered plant species, 6 endangered and 16 vulnerable animal species in project areas supported previously by SGP in Cerrado and 0 plant and animal species in Caatinga

target.comment: 50 plant species and 25 animal species, including Cerrado and Caatinga

actual.comment: 70 plant species and 10 animal species being conserved by the sustainable use

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of families participating in Caatinga and Cerrado bio-products marketing networks

baseline.comment: 6,000 families currently participate

target.comment: 8,000 additional families participate

actual.comment: 3,609 families are generating income through marketing of biodiversity products.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of hectares with forest cover under regeneration in community lands

baseline.comment: 612 hectares currently under regeneration

target.comment: 1000 additional hectares under natural regeneration practices

actual.comment: 4,153 hectares of Cerrado and Caatinga are under regeneration

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Carbon stocks maintained through avoiding land use change and improved agriculture and forest management at the community level

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of hectares under sustainable forest management in community lands

baseline.comment: 36,190 ha under sustainable forest management (in projects supported in OP4)

target.comment: 40,000 additional hectares under sustainable forest management

actual.comment: 12,547 hectares under sustainable forest management

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Area under ecological agriculture management

baseline.comment: 250 hectares (est.)

target.comment: 15,000 hectares under ecological agriculture management

actual.comment: 1,185 hectares under ecological agriculture management

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Area on which smallholders apply fire control techniques or avoid use of fire

baseline.comment: Smallholders do not currently apply fire control techniques or avoid the use of fire

target.comment: Smallholders apply fire control techniques or avoid the use of fire on at least 25,000 hectares

actual.comment: 6,224 hectares with fire control techniques being applied

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of families adopting sustainable water management techniques and sustainable land management techniques

baseline.comment: 517 families have adopted sustainable water management techniques and SLM techniques as a result of SGP support in OP4.

target.comment: 1200 additional families have adopted sustainable water management techniques and SLM techniques

actual.comment: 2,077 families have adopted sustainable water management techniques and SLM techniques

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Sustainable land management techniques preventing land degradation, restoring agro-ecosystem services, and improving livelihoods of local communities implemented

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Area with erosion in grantee farmlands

baseline.comment: 2400 ha of grantee farmland undergoing erosion, to be confirmed through project submissions

target.comment: Reduction of erosion in 1200 ha as a result of SGP interventions

actual.comment: 193 hectares where erosion control activities are being applied

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Area under sustainable water and soil management

baseline.comment: 1,200 ha in Cerrado

target.comment: 2000 ha (including Caatinga and Cerrado)

actual.comment:
29 hectares under sustainable water and soil management
There are also eight grants starting that estimate to contribute to over 10,000 hectares.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Communities deliver global environmental benefits through capacity development and knowledge management

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Percentage of project reports that receive a 'very good'? score, according to SGP Brazil project assessment method

baseline.comment: 51% very good

target.comment: 70% of project reports very good?

actual.comment: 85% of the reports presented in the period as \"very good\"

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of community leaders aware of global environmental issues

baseline.comment: 30 community leaders

target.comment: 150 additional community leaders

actual.comment: 1,605 community leaders aware of global environmental issues

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of policy inputs or recommendations provided to policymakers based on lessons learned

baseline.comment: 10 inputs or recommendations as a result of SGP support in OP4

target.comment: 10 additional inputs or recommendations

actual.comment:
- 7 recommendations and inputs to policy process.
- ISPN and indigenous grantees are contributing to the improvement of the National Policy for Indigenous Territory Management (PNGATI), within FUNAI - PPP-ECOS is being used as a delivery mechanism for the grants component of the GEF/GATI Project;
- Three grantees are closely linked in order to increase local traditional communities network (quilombolas, geraizeiros, fundo and fecho de pasto) that is struggling for territory guarantee in West of Bahia, against monoculture expansion and land grabbing.
- Based on our SGP experiences, ISPN has a seat on the Federal District Council for Food Security (CONSEA-DF) and coordinates the Agroecology Committee. The main influence in this period was a letter to the governor establishing guidelines for governmental action regarding agroecology. One of the achievements is the implementation of an innovative agroecological technical assistance in the Federal District.
- Based on our SGP experiences, ISPN has a seat on the National Council for Sustainable Rural Development (CONDRAF) which influenced for the inclusion of the wild collection on the National Government Multiannual Budget. Our participation in CONDRAF is contributing to a formal request for the National Government to hire technical assistance specially focused on the Cerrado biome.
- In partnership with ICRAF, Embrapa Cenargen (Embrapa Genetic Resources & Biotechnology, Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation) and IUCN, the workshop "Conservation through Agroforestry: paths for restoration among family farmers" were held in May 2015. The objective was to produce inputs for the new Forest Code regulation in Brazilian states regarding oportunities and requirements for restoration by small farmers. One of the results of the workshop was an Open Letter that will be sent to key Brazilian policy-making agencies, stating that agroforestry systems are strategic for reconciling conservation with livelihoods and that research, education and extension services need to be more geared towards family-based farming and agroforestry systems.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Pelo menos 90% dos requisitos de estrutura física e de logística demandados para os Jogos atendidos por meio do Projeto. 2. evento de abertura organizado e pelo menos 3 iniciativas de cunho social e ambiental realizadas 3. 100% do projeto executado de acordo com as normas do Organismo Internacional

baseline.comment: XIII Jogos dos Povos Indígenas realizados com sucesso que serviram de inspiração para o I Jogos Mundiais Indigenas

target.comment: 1. i) elaborar projetos executivos, termos de referência e especificações técnicas; ii) assinar contratos; iii) executar os serviços; iv) apresentar os relatórios finais de execução. 2. i) organização da cerimônia de abertura e encerramento dos Jogos; ii) identificação e execução dos projetos sociais e ambientais de interesse das partes e passíveis de serem executados durante os Jogos; iii relatoria das ações realizadas 3. i) definir a estrutura de gestão do Projeto; ii) contratar equipe de gestão e de execução; iii) prover meios para a execução e o monitoramento do projeto; iv) elaborar relatórios de progresso e de prestação de contas; v) relatoria, sistematização da experiência e lições aprendidas, registro de metodologias desenvolvidas 2016: i) realizar a auditoria do Projeto (cobrir custos financeiros, organizar documentação e preparar respostas).
